κλῆρος: (1) lot, a stone or potsherd, on which each man scratched his mark, . The lots were then shaken in a helmet, and he whose lot first sprang forth was thereby selected for the matter in hand.—(2) paternal estate, .
κλητός (καλέω): called, chosen, invited, , .
κλῖμαξ, ακος (κλίνω): stair-way, ladder. (Od.)
κλιντήρ, ῆρος: couch, sofa. (See cut.)

κλίνω, aor. ἔκλινα, κλῖναν, pass. aor. (ἐ）κλίνθη, ἐκλίθη, perf. 3 pl. κεκλίαται, κεκλιμένος, plup. κέκλιτο, mid. aor. part. κλινάμενος: I. act., make to slope or incline, lean one thing against another, τινί τι, or πρός τι, *λ 593, ; of turning away the eyes, ; turning the tide of battle (μάχην, inclinare pugnam), , and esp. put to flight, , .—II. pass., bend oneself, sink or lie down; ἐκλίνθη καὶ ἀλεύατο??ρα, ἑτέρωσ' ἐκλίνθη κάρη, κλίνθη κεκμηώς,, , ; be supported, lean against, τινί, *λ 371, , mid., .
κλισίη (κλίνω), dat. κλισίηφι: hut or lodge of shepherds, , , , ; barrack (not exactly ‘tent’) of warriors, ff; often in pl.; also couch or easy-chair, , . (See cut No. 73.)
κλισίηθεν: from the hut, from the barrack.
κλισίηνδε: to the hut, to the barrack.
κλίσιον (κλίνω): an adjoining building for servants, etc., †.
κλισμός (κλίνω): reclining chair, easy-chair, . (Cf. adjoining cut, or Nos. 105, 106.
κλιτύς, pl. acc. κλιτῦς: slope, hillside.
κλονέω, κλονέει, pass. κλονέονται, ipf. κλονέοντο: put to rout, drive in confusion, pass., be driven or rush wildly about; fig., of wind, driving clouds or flame, , ; pass., , . (Il.)
: leader of the Boeotiaus, slain by Agēnor, , .
κλόνος: tumult; ἐγχειάων, ‘press of spears,’ . (Il.)
κλόπιος: deceitful, †.
κλοτοπεύω: doubtful word, be wasting words or making fine speeches, †.
κλύδων, ωνος (κλύζω): surge, billow, †.
κλύζω, ipf. iter. κλύζεσκον: of waves, plash, dash, ; aor. pass., ‘was dashed high,’ ‘rose in foam,’ , , 541.
κλῦθι: see κλύω.
: (1) a Nereid, .—(2) an attendant of Helen, .—(3) daughter of Minyas or Iphis, mother of Iphiclus, .
: king of the Minyans in Orchomenus, father of Eurydice, mortally wounded at Thebes, .
: daughter of Tyndareus, sister of Helen, and wife of Agamemnon. She was slain at the same time that her paramour Aegisthus was killed by Orestes, , , 310, . (See cut No. 33.)
: son of Clytius.—(1) Dolops.—(2) Piraeus.
: (1) a son of Laomedon, brother of Priam, and father of Calētor, , 427, *γ 147, .—(2) father of Piraeus in Ithaca, .— (3) a Greek, the father of Dolops.
κλυτό - εργος (ϝέργον): maker of famous works, .
: son of Enops of Aetolia, beaten by Nestor in a boxingmatch, †.
: son of Alcinous, , 123.
κλυτό - πωλος: with famous steeds, epithet of Hades, ff. Probably said with reference to the rape of Proserpine. (Il.)
κλυτός, 2 and 3 (κλύω): illustrious, glorious, epith. of gods and men; then of things, famous, fine, ἄλσος, μῆλα, ἔργα, etc.; ὄνομα, , cf. .
κλυτο - τέχνης: famous in art, renowned artificer, epithet of Hephaestus.
κλυτό-τοξος: with glorious bow, illustrious archer, epith. of Apollo.

κλύω, ipf., w. aor. signif., ἔκλυον, κλύον, ἔκλυε, aor. 2 imp. κλῦθι, κλῦτε, redupl. κέκλυθι, κέκλυτε: hear, esp. hear willingly, hearken to prayer or entreaty; hence very often the imp., κλυθί μευ, ἀργυρότοξε, κέκλυτέ μευ μύθων, *α 37, ; also implying obedience, τοῦ μάλα μὲν κλύον ἠδ' ἐπίθοντο, *η 379, ; w. participle, ἔκλυον αὐδήσαντος, ; freq. w. acc. of thing heard.
: the ‘Spinsters,’ i. e. the Fates, †.
κλωμακόεις, εσσα: rock - terraced, rocky, †.
κνάω, ipf. (or aor.) κνῆ: grate (cheese), †.
κνέφας (cf. γνόφος, δνόφος): darkness, dusk, of the first part of the night.
κνῆ: see κνάω.
κνήμη: the part of the leg between knee and ankle, shin.

κνημίς, ῖδος (κνήμη): greave. The greaves were metal plates, lined with some soft material, bent around the shin-bone under the knee, and fastened by clasps at the ankle (see cut No. 36), thus only in the Iliad. In the Odyssey, , the word signifies leather leggins.
κνημός: only pl., mountain - valleys (saltus).
κνῆστις, dat. κνήστι (κνάω): grater, or knife for grating, †.

κνίση: the steam or savor of burnt offerings, originally fat, esp. that of the caul or diaphragm, in which the thighs of the victim were wrapped. It was then laid upon the fire and burned, together with pieces of flesh piled upon it, .
κνισήεις, εν: redolent of savory viands, †.
κνυζηθμός (κνύζω): whimpering, of dogs, †.
κνυζόω, fut. -ώσω, aor. κνύζωσε: render dim or lustreless, and 433.
κνώδαλον: wild animal, †.
: Cnosus, the principal city in Crete, , , .
κνώσσω: slumber, †.
κοῖλος (cf. cavus): hollow; often of places between mountains, ὁδός, *λακεδαίμων,, ; λιμήν, ‘deepembosomed,’ i. e. extending far into the land, .

κοιμάω (cf. κεῖμαι), aor. (ἐ）κοίμησα, mid. ipf. κοιμᾶτο, κοιμῶντο, aor. (ἐ）κοιμήσατο, pass. aor. (ἐ）κοιμήθην: act., put to bed or to rest, , ; lull to sleep, τινὰ ὕπνῳ, ; fig. of winds, ; mid. and pass., lie down to sleep or to rest (esp. w. reference to the comfort or discomfort of the resting-place), sleep; fig. of the sleep of death, .
κοιρανέω (κοίρανος): belord or ruler, rule, ἀνά, κατά, διά τινας, whether in war or peace; of the suitors of Penelope, ‘playing the lord,’ ‘lording it,’ .
κοίρανος (cf. κῦρος): lord, ruler, master, .
: (1) a Lycian, slain by Odysseus, .—(2) from Lyctus in Crete, charioteer of Meriones, slain by Hector, , 614.
κοίτη (κεῖμαι): bed, †.
κοῖτος: night's rest, sleep, then resting-place, .
κολεόν, κουλεόν: sheath or scabbard of a sword, made of metal, and decorated with ivory, ff., .
κολλήεις (κολλάω): ξυστὰ ναύμαχα κολλήεντα, ship - spears united with rings, †.
κολλητός (κολλάω): joined, wellcompacted or ‘shod,’ with bands or otherwise, δίφρος, σανίδες,, , .
κόλλοψ, οπος: peg of a lyre, round which the string was fastened, †.
κολοιός: jack-daw. (Il.)
κόλος: docked, pointless, †.
κολοσυρτός: noisy rout, of the hunt, and .
κολούω (κόλος): cut short, curtail, only fig., , , .
κόλπος: bosom, also of the fold of the garment about neck and breast, ; fig. of the sea, θαλάσσης, ἁλός.
κολῳάω (κολῳός), ipf. ἑκολῴᾶ: bawl, †.
κολώνη: hill. (Il.)
κολῳός: noisy wrangling, racket, †.
κομάω (κόμη): only part., wearing long hair; κάρη κομόωντες *̓αχαιοί, ‘long-haired Achaeans;’ , i. e. shorn in front, ; ἐθείρῃσι, ‘with long manes,’ .
κομέω, κομέουσι, ipf. ἐκόμει, κομείτην, iter. κομέεσκε: take care of, tend, by affording food, bed, clothing, bath, ; of animals, , 319.
κόμη: hair of the head, with reference to comeliness, pl., locks, ; then foliage, .
κομιδή: care, attendance, bestowed on persons, horses, garden, , 247.

κομίζω (κομέω), fut. κομιῶ, aor. κόμισσα, (ἐ）κόμισε, mid. aor. (ἐ）κομίσσατο, κομίσαντο: I. act. (1) wait upon, attend, care for, esp. entertain as guest, , , cf. 111; of feeling (τινά τινι), ; pass., .—(2) take or bring away to be cared for, fetch, convey, , , , , , .—II. mid., take to one's care, entertain hospitably, take or convey home or to oneself, , , , , ; of carrying off a spear in one's body, .
κομπέω: clash, †.
κόμπος: clashing; ‘stamping’ of feet, ; ‘gnashing’ of the tusks of a wild boar, , .
κοναβέω, aor. κονάβησα: resound, ring, of echoing and of metallic objects, πήληξ, νῆες, δῶμα. (Il. and .)
κοναβίζω = κοναβέω. (Il.)
κόναβος: din, †.
κονίη: dust, sand, ashes, , , .
κόνις, ιος, dat. κόνι=κονίη.
κονίσαλος: dust - cloud, dust - whirl. (Il.)

κονίω, fut. κονίσουσι, aor. ἐκόνισα, pass. perf. part. κεκονιμένος, plup. κεκόνιτο: make dust or make dusty, cover with dust; pass., , ; intr., κονίοντες πεδίοιο, ‘scampering’ over the plain in a cloud of dust.
κοντός: punting-pole, pole, †.
: the father of Periphētes, herald of Eurystheus, †.
κοπρέω: only fut. part. κοπρήσοντες, for manuring the fields, †.
κόπρος: dung, manure, ; then ‘farm-yard,’ ‘cow-yard,’ .
κόπτω, aor. κόψε, perf. part. κεκοπώς, mid. aor. κόψατο: knock, smite, hammer, , , mid., oneself or a part of oneself, .
πέτρη: Raven's Rock, in Ithaca, †.

κορέννυμι, fut. κορέω, aor. ἐκόρεσα, pass. perf. κεκόρημαι, part., act. w. pass. signif., κεκορηώς, aor. pass. (ἐ）κορέσθην, aor. mid. (ἐ）κορέσατο: sate, satisfy, τινά τινι, ; mid., satisfy oneself, τινός; met., have enough of, be tired of, w. gen. or participle, .
κορέω, aor. imp. κορήσατε: sweep, sweep out, †.
κόρη: see κούρη.
κορθύομαι (κόρυς): rise to a head, tower up, †.
κορμός (κείρω): log, trunk of a tree, †.
κόρος: satiety, surfeit, τινός.
κόροη (κάρη): temple. (Il.)
κορυθ-άϊξ (ἀίσσω): helmet-shaking, with waving plume, †.
κορυθ-αίολος: with glancing helm; epith., esp. of Hector and Ares. (Il.)
κόρυμβος, pl. κόρυμβα (cf. κόρυς, κάρη): pl., the heads, bow-ends of a vessel, cf. ἄφλαστα, †. (See cut No. 38.)
κορύνη: battle - mace, club of iron. (Il.)
κορυνήτης: club-brandisher. (Il.)

κόρυς (cf. κάρη), acc. κόρυθα and κόρυν: helmet; epithets, βριαρή, δαιδαλέη, ἱπποδάσεια, ἱππόκομος, λαμπομένη, λαμπρή, παναίθη, τετράφαλος, φαεινή, χαλκήρεος, χαλκοπάρῃος. (See cuts under these adjectives.)

κορύσσω, mid. aor. part. κορυσσάμενος, pass. perf. part. κεκορυθμένος: arm the head with the helmet; then, in general, arm, equip, mid., arm oneself; of weapons, κεκορυθμένα χαλκῷ, with head of bronze, bronze-shod, , ; met., πόλεμον, κῦμα (cf. κορθύομαι), , .
κορυστής, du. κορυστά: helmeted, hence armed, equipped for battle. (Il.)
κορυφή (cf. κόρυς, κάρη): crest, summit. (Il. and .)
: Coronēa, a city in Boeotia, south of lake Copāis, †.

κορώνη: anything crooked or curved. —(1) the ring on a door, . (See cuts Nos. 68 and 56.)—(2) the curved end of the bow over which the loop of the bow-string was brought. (See cut No. 34.)—(3) sea-crow cormorant,, 66.
κορωνίς, ίδος (κορώνη): curved, epith. of ships; always νηυσὶ (or νήεσσι) κορωνίσιν. (See cuts Nos. 38, 87, 88.)
: son of Caeneus, father of Leonteus, king of the Lapithae, †.
κοσμέω (κόσμος), aor. ἐκόσμησα, pass. aor. 3 pl. κόσμηθεν, mid. aor. part. κοσμησάμενος: arrange, order, esp. marshall troops, mid., one's own men, ; of preparing a meal, .
κοσμητός: well laid out, †.
κοσμήτωρ, ορος: marshaller, in Il. always κοσμήτορε λαῶν, of the Atrīdae and the Dioscūri; sing., .

κόσμος: order, arrangement, then ornaments (of women), trappings (of horses); of building or construction, ἵππου (the wooden), ; freq. κόσμῳ, and (εὖ) κατὰ κόσμον, both literally and figuratively, ‘duly,’ ‘becomingly,’ ; also οὐ κατὰ κόσμον, .
κοτέω, κοτέομαι, perf. part. κεκοτηώς, mid. aor. κοτέσσατο: be angry with, τινί, also w. causal gen., .
κοτήεις: wrathful, †.
κότος: grudge, rancor, wrath.
κοτύλη: little cup, hip-joint, .
κοτυληδών, όνος, dat. pl. κοτυληδονόφιν: pl., suckers at the ends of the tentaculae of a polypus, †.
κοτυλ-ήρυτος (ἀρύω): that may be caught in cups, streaming, †.
κουλεόν: see κολεόν.
κούρη: young girl, daughter; also of young married women, .
κούρητες (κοῦρος), pl.: youths, usually princes.
: the Curētes, a tribe in Aetolia, afterward expelled by the Aetolians; their siege of Calydon, -599.
κουρίδιος: doubtful word, regular, wedded, epith. of ἄλοχος, πόσις, λέχος, as opposed to irregular connections; δῶμα, house of the husband, or princely house, ; as subst. (=πόσις), .
κουρίζω: only part., when a young man, †.
κουρίξ: adv., by the hair, †.

κοῦρος: youth, boy, esp. of noble rank, so when applied to the attendants at sacrifices and banquets, as these were regularly the sons of princely houses, , ; also implying vigorous youth, ability to bear arms, ; son, .
κουρότερος: younger; as subst., .
κουρο-τρόφος: nourisher of youths, †.
κοῦφος: light, agile; adv., κοῦφα, quickly, ; κουφότερον, with lighter heart, .
: son of Antēnor, slain by Agamemnon, -260, .
: see .
κράατα, κράατι, κράατος: see κάρη.
κραδαίνω = κραδάω, only mid. part., quivering. (Il.)
κραδάω, part. κραδάων: brandish.

κραίνω, κραιαίνω, κραίνουσι, ipf. ἐκραίαινε, aor. imp. κρήηνον, κρῆνον, inf. κρηῆναι, κρῆναι, mid. fut. inf. κρανέεσθαι (for κεκράανται, -ντο, see κεράννυμι): accomplish, fulfil, bring to pass; fut. mid. as pass., ; ‘bear sway,’ .
κραιπνός, comp. κραιπνότερος: rapid, quick; fig., hasty, νόος, .— Adv., κραιπνῶς, also κραιπνά, .
: name of an island, .
κραναός: rocky, epith. of Ithaca.
κρανέεσθαι: see κραίνω.
κράνεια: cornel-tree, , .
κρανίον (κρᾶνον): upper part of the skull, †.
(later ): an island near Rhodes, .
κρᾶτα, κρατί: see κάρη.
κραται-γύαλος: with strong breastplates, †. (See cut No. 55.)
κραταιίς: overpowering force, ‘weight’ we should say, i. e. the force of gravitation, in the stone of Sisyphus, .—Personified, , Crataeis, the mother of Scylla, .
κραταί-πεδος (πέδον): with strong (hard) footing or surface, †.
κρατερός, καρτερός, κρατερῆφι: strong, powerful, mighty, of persons and things, and sometimes in bad sense, μῦθος, ‘stern,’ .—Adv., κρατερῶς.
κρατερό-φρων: stout-hearted, dauntless.
κρατερ-ῶνυξ (ὄνυξ): strong-hoofed, strong-clawed.
κράτεσφι: see κάρη.

κρατευταί: explained by Aristarchus as head-stones, on which the spits were rested in roasting meat; cf. our ‘fire - dogs,’ ‘andirons.’ Possibly the shape was like the horns (κέρας) on the altar in cut No. 95. †.
κρατέω (κράτος): be superior in might, have power, rule over, τινός, sometimes τισίν (among), , ; κρατέων, ‘with might.’
κράτος, κάρτος, εος: superior strength, might, power, then mastery, victory, , .
κρατός: see κάρη.
κρατύς = κρατερός, epith. of Hermes.
κρεῖον (κρέας): meat-tray, dresser, †.
κρείσσων, ον: stronger, superior in strength or might, better; w. inf., .
: son of Creon, Lycomēdes, †.
κρείων, ουσα, properly part.: ruling, ruler; εὐρὺ κρείων, ‘ruling far and wide,’ title esp. of Agamemnon, as generalissimo of the Greek forces; also of Zeus and Poseidon; more freely applied, .
: Creon.—(1) a king of Thebes, the father of Megara, . —(2) father of Lycomēdes.
κρεμάννυμι, κρέμαμαι, fut. κρεμόω, aor. κρέμασε, mid. ipf. (ἐ）κρέμω: hang, hang up, mid. intrans., .
κρεῶν: see κρέας.
κρήγυος: good, useful, helpful, †.
κρήδεμνον (κάρη, δέω): head-band; in women's attire, a short veil, as seen in the cut, ; also of the ‘battlements’ of cities, ; ‘lid’ of a wine-jar, . (See cut No. 64.)
κρηῆναι: see κραίνω.
κρῆθεν: see κατάκρηθεν.
: Cretheus, of Iolcus, the husband of Tyro, , 258.
: son of Diocles, slain by Aenēas, , 549.
κρημνός (κρέμαμαι): steep, over hanging bank, often of the gullied banks of the Scamander, , 175.
κρηναῖος (κρήνη): of the fount, νύμφαι, fountain-nymphs, †.
κρήνη: fount, spring; κρήνηνδε, to the spring, . (Cf. cut No. 61.)
, pl. : the Cretans, inhabitants of Crete.
, also pl. : Crete; epithets, ἑκατόμπολις, εὐρεῖα,, , to Crete, ; *κρήτηθεν, from Crete, .

κρητήρ, ῆρος (κεράννυμι): mixingbowl, wassail-bowl, in which wine and water were mingled, to be distributed in cups; two parts of wine to three of water was a common mixture; κρητῆρα μίσγεσθαι, στήσασθαι, ‘set up,’ place at hand. The wassail-bowl was usually placed near the hearth, and often on a tripod (esp. when several κρητῆρες were in use at the banquet); the contents were poured into the cups (δέπαα) by means of a filler (πρόχοος, pitcher), . Cut No. 8 shows (1) the ἀμφιφορεύς, from which the wine was poured into the upper, smaller mixing-bowl, on which the πρόχοος stands. The second mixing-bowl served to contain the water, and then the contents of both bowls may be imagined as mixed in the largest bowl, which stands upon the tripod, and from which the diluted wine was distributed. (Cf. cut No. 26.)
κρῖ = κριθή.
κρίζω, aor. 2 κρίκε: creak, said of the yoke under a strain, .
κριθή, only pl. κριθαί: barley, barleycorn.
κρίκε: see κρίζω.
κρίκος (κίρκος): yoke-ring, †. (See adjoining cut, from the antique; still clearer are cuts Nos. 42, 45.)

κρίνω, imp. κρῖνε, pass. perf. part. κεκριμένος, aor. κρινθέντες, mid. aor. ἐκρίνατο, subj. κρίνωνται, inf. κρίνασθαι, part. κρινάμενος: I. act., separate, καρπόν τε καὶ ἄχνας, ; hence of arranging troops, ; then select, ; freq. the pass., , ; decide (cernere), νεῖκος, θέμιστας,, ; οὖρος κεκρι- μένος, a ‘decided’ wind, .—II. mid., select or choose for oneself;, ; get a contest decided, ‘measure oneself’ in battle, κρίνεσθαι *̓́αρηι (decernere proelio), ; abs. , cf. ; of ‘interpreting’ dreams, .
κριός: ram. (Od.)
: a town in Phocis, near Delphi, termed ζαθέη, .
κριτός (κρίνω): chosen, and .
κροαίνω (κρούω): gallop. (Il.)
: a Trojan, slain by Meges, †.
κροκό-πεπλος: with saffron-colored mantle, saffron - robed; epith. of Eos. (Il.)
κρόκος: saffron, †.
: an island or a village belonging to Ithaca, †.
κρόμυον: onion.
: son of Cronus, Zeus, often used alone without , .
: Cronus (Saturnus), the father of Zeus, Poseidon, Hades, Hera, Demēter, and Hestia; overthrown with the Titans, , 479, 383, .
κρόσσαι (cf. κόρση, κάρη): πύργων, walls or breasting of the towers, between foundations and battlements, , 444.
κρόταφος (cf. κόρση, κάρη): temples of the head, , ; usually pl.
κροτέω (κρότος) = κροταλίζω, †.
: ‘Springs,’ a place in Elis, †.
κρουνός: source, spring. (Il.)
κρύβδα, κρύβδην: secretly.
κρυερός (κρύος): chilling, dread.
κρυόεις = κρυερός. (Il.)
κρυπτάδιος: secret; κρυπτάδια φρονέοντα δικαζέμεν, ‘harbor secret counsels,’ .
κρυπτός: concealed, secret, †.

κρύπτω, ipf. iter. κρύπτασκε, fut. κρύψω, aor. ἔκρυψα, pass. aor. κρύφθη, perf. part. κεκρυμμένος: hide, conceal, sometimes implying protection, τινὰ σάκεϊ, κεφαλὰς κορύθεσσι, cf. καλύπτω; pass., κρύφθη ὑπ ἀσπίδι, ‘hid himself,’ ; met., ‘keep secret,’ ἔπος τινί, .
κρύσταλλος: clear ice, ice, and .
κρυφηδόν: secretly, and .
: a locality in Paphlagonia, †.
κτάμεν: see κτείνω.
κτέαρ, dat. pl. κτεάτεσσι: pl., possessions, property.
κτεατίζω, aor. κτεάτισσα=κτάομαι.
: son of Actor and Molione, .

κτείνω, ipf. κτεῖνον, iter. κτείνεσκε, fut. κτενέει, part. κτανέοντα, aor. ἔκτεινα, κτεῖνε, aor. 2 ἔκτανον, κτάνον, also ἔκτα, ἔκταμεν, ἔκταν, subj. κτέωμεν, inf. κτάμεναι, pass. pres. inf. κτεινεσθαι, aor. 3 pl. ἔκταθεν, aor. 2 mid., w. pass. signif., κτάσθαι, κτάμενος: kill, slay, esp. in battle; rarely of animals, , , ; pass., ; aor. mid. as pass., .
κτέρας = κτέαρ, and .
κτέρεα, pl.: possessions burned in honor of the dead upon the funeralpyre, hence funeral honors, obsequies (extremi honores), always with κτερεΐζειν.

κτερίζω̈, κτερεΐζω, inf. κτερεϊζέμεν, fut. κτεριῶ, aor. opt. κτερίσειε, inf. κτερεΐξαι: bury with solemn honors; ἀέθλοις, ‘celebrate one's funeral with games,’ ; ἐπὶ (adv.) κτερέα κτερεΐξαι, ‘bestow funeral honors upon’ one, , .
κτῆμα (κτάομαι): possession, property, sing., ; elsewhere pl., in the Iliad mostly of treasures, , .
: the father of Eumaeus, †.
: son of Polytherses, from Same, one of the suitors of Penelope, slain by Philoetius, , , 285.
κτῆσις, ιος (κτάομαι): property.
κτητός: that may be acquired, I 407†.
κτίδεος (ἰκτίς): of weasel-skin; κυνέη, and 458.
κτίζω, aor. ἔκτισα, κτίσσε: settle, found, a city or land.
κτίλος: ram, and .
: daughter of Laertes, sister of Odysseus, settled in marriage in Same, .
κτυπέω, aor. ἔκτυπε: crash, thunder; of falling trees, the bolts of Zeus.
κτύπος: any loud noise such as a crash, thunder; of the stamping of the feet of men, or the hoofs of horses, the tumult of battle, and the bolts of Zeus, , , .
κύαμος: bean, pl., †.
κυάνεος (κύανος): of steel, , then steel-blue, dark blue, dark; of the brows of Zeus, ; the hair of Hector, ; a serpent, ; earth or sand, ; and esp. νεφέλη, νέφος, even in metaphor, , .
κυανό-πεζα: with steel-blue feet, τράπεζα, †.
κυανό-πρῳρος and κυανο-πρῴρειος (πρῴρᾶ): dark - prowed, dark - bowed, epith. of ships.
κύανος: probably blue steel, , 35, and .
κυανο-χαίτης and κῦανο-χαῖτα: the dark-haired, epith. of Poseidon, also as subst.; dark-maned, ἵππος, .
κυαν-ῶπις, ιδος: dark-eyed, †.
κυβερνάω, aor. inf. κυβερνῆσαι: steer, νῆα, †.
κυβερνήτης, εω, and κυβερνητήρ, ῆρος: helmsman, pilot. (Od.)
κυβιστάω (κύβη, head, found only in glossaries), ipf. κυβίστων: turn somersaults, tumble, , 749; of fishes, .
κυβιστητήρ, ῆρος: tumbler; diver, .
κυδαίνω (κῦδος), aor. κύδηνε, inf. κυδῆναι: glorify, ennoble; θυμόν, rejoice, trans., .
κυδάλιμος (κῦδος): glorious, noble, epith. of persons, and of κῆρ, as typical of the person.
κυδάνω: glorify, exalt; intrans., exult, .
κυδι-άνειρα: man-ennobling, ἀγορή, μάχη. (Il.)
κυδιάω, part. κυδιόων: triumph, be proud. (Il.)
κύδιστος: most glorious.
κυδοιμέω, aor. κυδοίμησαν: rush tumultuously, spread confusion; trans., throw into confusion, .
κυδοιμός: uproar, confusion, din or mêlée of battle; personified, , .
κῦδος, εος: glory, majesty, might; of persons, in address, μέγα κῦδος *̓αχαιῶν, ‘pride of the Greeks,’ Nestor and Odysseus, , .
κυδρός: glorious, illustrious, always κυδρὴ παράκοιτις.
: the Cydonians, a tribe in the northwest of Crete, , .
κυέω: conceive, carry in the womb; of a mare with mule foal, .
κύθε: see κεύθω.
: Cytherēa, epithet of Aphrodite, from the island of Cythēra.

, pl.: Cythēra, an island off the coast of Laconia, S.W. of the promontory of Malēa, where the worship of Aphrodite had been introduced by an early Phoenician colony, , . —, from Cythēra, . —Adj. , of Cythēra, , .
κυκάω, part. κυκόωντι, ipf. ἐκύκα, aor. κύκησε, pass. κυκήθην: stir up, stir in, mix up; met., only pass., be stirred up, ‘panic-stricken,’ ; of waves and the sea, foam up, be in commotion, , .
κυκεών, acc. κυκεῶ: a mixed drink, compounded of barley meal, grated cheese, and wine, ; Circe adds also honey, , 234.
κυκλέω: wheel away, carry forth, of corpses, †.

κύκλος, pl. κύκλοι and κύκλα: ring, circle; δόλιος, employed by hunters for capturing game, ; ἱερός, the solemn circle of a tribunal, etc., ; wheel, , pl., τὰ κύκλα, *ε 722, ; of the rings on the outside of a shield, or the layers which, lying one above the other and gradually diminishing in size toward the boss, made up the whole disc, , .
κυκλόσε: in a circle, and .
κυκλο-τερής, ές (τείρω): circular, ; stretch or draw ‘into a circle,’ .

, pl. : Cyclops, pl., the Cyclōpes; sing., Polyphēmus, whose single eye was blinded by Odysseus, . The Cyclōpes are in Homer a lawless race of giants, dwelling without towns, social ties, or religion, .
κύκνος: swan.
κυλίνδω, part. neut. κυλίνδον, pass. ipf. (ἐ）κυλίνδετο, aor. κυλίσθη: roll; , ; fig., πῆμά τινι, ; pass., be rolled, roll, of a stone, ; of persons in violent demonstrations of grief, , ; met., , .
: Cyllēne, a mountain-chain in northern Arcadia, .
: Cyllenian.—(1) epith. of Hermes, from his birthplace, Mt. Cyllēne in Arcadia, .—(2) an inhabitant of the town Cyllēne in Elis, .
κυλλο-ποδίων, voc. -πόδιον (κυλλός, πούς): crook-footed, epith. of Hephaestus. (Il.)
κυμαίνω: only part., πόντον κυμαίνοντα, billowy deep. (Od.)
κύμβαχος: head foremost, ; as subst., crown or top of a helmet, the part in which the plume is fixed, . (See cuts Nos. 16 and 17.)
κύμινδις: night-hawk, called in the older language χαλκίς, .
and : Nereids, , 41†.
κυνά-μυια: dog-fly, an abusive epithet applied by Ares to Athēna, .

κυνέη: properly ‘dog - skin,’ a soldier's cap, generally of leather, ταυρείη,; κτιδέη, ; also mounted with metal, χαλκήρης, χαλκοπάρῃος, and πάγχαλκος, helmet, ; the κυνέη αἰγείη was a goat - skin cap for country wear (like that of the oarsmen in cut No. 38), ; *̓́αιδος, the cap of Hades, rendered the wearer invisible, .
κύνεος: dog - like, i. e. shameless, †.

κυνέω, ipf. κύνεον, κύνει, aor. ἔκυσα, κύσε, inf. κύσσαι: kiss; κύσσε δέ μιν κεφαλήν τε καὶ ἄμφω φᾶεα καλὰ | χειράς τ' ἀμφοτέρας (this shows the range of the word), , cf. ; ἄρουραν, his native soil, .
κυν-ηγέτης (κύων, ἡγέομαι): literally leader of dogs, i. e. hunter, pl., †.
κυνο-ραιστής (ῥαίω): literally dogbreaker (cf. ‘house-breaker’), i. e. flea, pl., †.
: a harbor-town of Locris, †.
κύντερος, comp., sup. κύντατος: more (most) dog like, i. e. shameless, impudent, audacious, .
κυν - ώπης, voc. κυνῶπα, and κυνῶπις, ιδος: literally dog-faced, i. e. impudent, shameless.
: a town in Elis, †.
κυπαρίσσινος: of cypress wood, †.
κυπάρισσος: cypress, evergreen, †.
κύπειρον: fragrant marsh - grass, perhaps ‘galingal,’ used as food for horses, .
κύπελλον: drinking - cup, goblet, , cf. 285, .
: Cypris, epith. of Aphrodīte, from the island of Cyprus, .
: the island of Cyprus, , to Cyprus, .
κύπτω, aor. opt. κύψει（ε), part. κύψας: bend the head, bow down. (Il. and .)
κυρέω, κύρω, ipf. κῦρε, aor. inf. κυρῆσαι, part. κύρσας, mid. pres. κύρεται: chance upon, encounter, ipf. try to hit, aim, ; w. ἐπί or dat. merely, ; of colliding in the race, . Cf. τυγχάνω.
κύρμα (κυρέω): what one chances upon, hence prey, booty; usually with ἕλωρ, .
κύρσας: see κυρέω.
κυρτός: curved, rounded, arched. (Il.)
κυρτόω: make curved; κῦμα κυρτωθέν, ‘arched,’ †.
κύστις: bladder. (Il.)
: a town in Paphlagonia, .
κυφός (κύπτω): bowed, bent, †.
: a town in Perrhaebia in Thessaly, †.
κύω: see κυέω and κυνέω.

κύων, κυνός, acc. κύνα, voc. κύον, pl. dat. κύνεσσι: dog, bitch; κύνες θηρευταί, τραπεζῆες, ‘hunting’ and ‘lapdogs,’ , i. e. Cerberus, , ; ‘sea-dog,’ perhaps seal, ; dog of Orīon, Sirius, ; as symbol of shamelessness, applied to women and others, ; λυσσητήρ, ‘raging hound,’ .
κῶας, pl. κώεα, dat. κώεσιν: fleece, serving for seat or bedding, , , .
κώδεια: poppy-head, †.
κωκυτός (κωκύω): wailing. As proper name , Cocȳtus, river of the nether world, .
κωκύω, aor. κώκυς（ε), part. κωκύσασα: wail, always of women's voices; sometimes trans., ‘bewail,’ τινά, .
κώληψ, ηπος: bend or hollow of the knee, †.
κῶμα (κοιμάω): deep sleep.
: a town on lake Copāis in Boeotia, †.
κώπη: handle of sword or oar, hilt, oar; of a key, . (See cut No. 68.)
κωπήεις: hilted.
κώρυκος: leather knapsack or wallet. (Od.)
: the island of Cos, , to Cos, .
κωφός (κόπτω): blunted, ; ‘dull - sounding,’ of a wave before it breaks, ; κωφὴ γαῖα, dull, ‘senseless’ dust, of a dead body, .

div1.head: *l
div1.entryFree: λᾶας, λᾶος, dat. λᾶι, acc. λᾶαν, du. λᾶε, pl. gen. λάων, dat. λάεσσι: stone.
: a town in Laconia, †.
λαβρ - αγόρης (λάβρος): reckless talker, †.
λαβρεύομαι: talk rashly, and .
λάβρος, sup. λαβρότατος: rapid, rushing.

λαγχάνω, aor. ἔλαχον, λάχεν, redupl. subj. λελάχητε, perf. λέλογχεν: obtain by lot or by destiny, obtain, receive; abs., ; reversing the usual relation, , ‘won me to her power at my birth,’ ; w. part. gen., , ; causative, ‘put in possession of,’ ‘honor with,’ θανόντα πυρός, only with redupl. aor., , etc.; intrans., ‘fall by lot,’ .
λαγωός (Att. λαγώς): hare.
: (1) son of Aemon, father of Alcimedon, a Myrmidon, .— (2) a goldsmith in Pylos, .
: Laertes, son of Arcīsius, and father of Odysseus, king in Ithaca, , , 270,, 555, χ 185, ff.
: son of Laertes, Odysseus.
λάζομαι (=λαμβάνω), opt. 3 pl. λαζοίατο, ipf. (ἐ）λάζετο: take; γαῖαν ὀδάξ, ‘bite the dust,’ ; μῦθον πάλιν, ‘caught back again’ the words (of joy which were on his lips), .
λαθι-κηδής, ές (κῆδος): causing to forget care, ‘banishing care,’ †.
λάθρῃ: secretly, unbeknown, τινός, ‘to one’; ‘imperceptibly,’ .
λάϊγξ, ιγγος: pebble. (Od.)
λαῖλαψ, απος: tempest of wind and rain, hurricane.
λαιμός: throat, gullet. (Il.)
λαΐνεος and λάϊνος (λᾶας): of stone, stony; τεῖχος, in the interpolated passage, .
λαισήιον: light shield or target; λαισήια πτερόεντα, perhaps so called on account of the ‘fluttering’ apron of untanned leather (λάσιος) hanging from the shield. (See adjoining cut and esp. No. 79.)
: Laestrygonian, , .
, pl. : Laestrȳgon, the Laestrȳgons, a tribe of savage giants, , 119, 199.
λαῖτμα: the great gulf or abyss of the sea, usually w. ἁλός or θαλάσσης. (Od. and .)
λαῖφος, εος: shabby, tattered garment, and .
λαιψηρός: nimble, swift; adv., λαιψηρὰ ἐνώμα, ‘plied nimbly,’ .
λάκε: see λάσκω.
λακτίζω: kick with the heel, of the mortally wounded, struggling convulsively, and .

λαμβάνω, only aor. 2 act. and mid., ἔλλαβ（ε), ἐλλάβετ（ο), inf. redupl. λελαβέσθαι: take, receive, mid., take hold of; freq. w. part. gen.; sometimes of ‘seizing,’ ‘taking captive,’ , ; in friendly sense, ‘take in,’ ; met., of feelings, χόλος, πένθος, τρόμος, etc.
: the king of the Laestrȳgons, †.
λαμπετάω = λάμπω.
: son of Lampus, Dolops, †.
: a nymph, daughter of Helius, , 375.
: (1) son of Laomedon, father of the Trojan Dolops, , .—(2) name of one of the steeds of Eos, .—(3) one of Hector's horses, .
λαμπρός, sup. λαμπρότατος: bright, brilliant, shining. (Il. and .)
λαμπτήρ, ῆρος: fire - pan, lightstand, cresset, to hold blazing pine splinters for illuminating, , . (See cuts, after bronze originals from Pompeii.)
λάμπω, ipf. ἔλαμπ（ε), λάμφ̓: shine, gleam, be radiant or brilliant.

λανθάνω, λήθω, ipf. (ἐ）λάνθανον, ἔληθον, λῆθεν, iter. λήθεσκε, fut. λήσω, aor. 2 ἔλαθον, λάθον, subj. redupl. λε- λάθῃ, mid. λήθομαι, ipf. λανθανόμην, aor. 2 λάθετο, redupl. λελάθοντο, opt. 3 pl. λαθοίατο, imp. redupl. λελαθέσθω, perf. λέλασται, part. λελασμένος: I. act., escape the notice of, τινά, the obj. of the Greek verb usually appearing as the subj. in Eng., οὐδέ σε λήθω, ‘nor dost thou ever fail to mark me,’ , ; the thing that one does when somebody else fails to mark him is regularly expressed by the part., ἄλλον πού τινα μᾶλλον *̓αχαιῶν χαλκοχιτώνων | λήθω μαρνάμενος, σὲ δὲ ϝιδμεναι αὐτὸν ὀίω, ‘another perchance is likely enough to overlook my prowess, but you know it right well,’ . The learner cannot afford to be careless about the above meaning and construction. Sometimes w. ὅτι or ὅπως, ὅτε, . The redupl. aor. is causative, make to forget; τινά τινος, .—II. mid., forget; τινός, *δ 127, .
λάξ: adv., with the heel, with ποδί, and .
: (1) a Trojan, the son of Onētor, slain by Meriones, . —(2) a Trojan, the son of Bias, slain by Achilles, .
: (1) son of Antēnor, slain by Ajax, .—(2) a Phaeacian, son of Alcinous, , 132, η 170, , 141.
: daughter of Bellerophon, and mother of Sarpēdon, .
: Laodice.—(1) a daughter of Agamemnon, , 287.—(2) a daughter of Priam, wife of Helicāon, , .
: (1) a son of Antēnor, .—(2) a comrade of Antilochus, .
: daughter of Altes, mother of Lycāon, , .
: son or descendant of Laomedon.—(1) Priam, .—(2) Lampus, .

: Laomedon, son of Ilus and father of Priam. He had promised his daughter Hesione to Heracles, on condition of her being delivered from the sea-monster sent by Poseidon to ravage the Troad, but proving false to his agreement was slain by Heracles, ff., 269, , , .
λαός, pl. λαοί: people, host, esp. army; sometimes crew, crews, ; oftener the pl. than the sing., , .
λαο-σσόος (σεύω): driving the people on (to combat), rousing the people; epith. of Ares, Eris, Athēne (Apollo, Amphiarāus), , .
λαο - φόρος: ὁδός, public way, †.
λαπάρη: the soft part of the body between hips and ribs, flank, loins. (Il.)
: the Lapithae, a warlike tribe dwelling by Mts. Olympus and Pelion in Thessaly, , 181, .
λάπτω, fut. part. λάψοντες: lap up with the tongue, †.
: a town in Asia Minor, near Cyme, , .
λάρναξ, ακος: chest, ; vase or urn, .
λάρος: a sea bird, cormorant, with ὄρνις, †.
λαρός, sup. λαρώτατος: rich, fine, well-relished, .
λάσιος: hairy, shaggy, epith. of στῆθος, also κῆρ, as sign of manly strength and spirit; of sheep, wolly, .
λάσκω, aor. 2 λάκε, perf. part. w. pres. signif. λεληκώς, λελακυῖα: give voice, of animals, Scylla (as dog), a falcon, ; of things, sound, χαλκός, ἀσπίς, ὀστέα. (Il. and .)
λαυκανίη: throat, gullet. (Il.)
λαύρη: lane, side - passage between the house (of Odysseus) and the outer wall of the court, , 137. (See plate III., o, n.）
λαφύσσω: gulp down, swallow. (Il.)
λάχε: see λαγχάνω.
λάχεια: with good soil for digging, fertile, νῆσος, and .
λαχνήεις: hairy, shaggy. (Il.)
λάχνος = λάχνη, wool, †.
λάω, part. λάων, ipf. λάε: doubtful word, ‘bury the teeth in,’ of a dog strangling a fawn, f.

λέβης, ητος: kettle, caldron, for warming water or for boiling food over fire, ; in the Odyssey usually, basin, wash-basin, held under the hands or feet while water was poured from a pitcher over them, ; called ἀνθεμόεις, from the decoration, .

λέγω, ipf. ἔλεγ̓, λέγε, λέγομεν, fut. part. λέξοντες, aor. ἔλεξεν, imp. λέξον, mid. pres. subj. λεγώμεθα, ipf. λέγοντο, fut. λέξομαι, aor. λέξατο, aor. 2 ἐλέγμην, ἔλεκτο, λέκτο, imp. λέξο, λέξεο, pass. aor. ἐλέχθην. The above forms are common to two distinct roots λεγ, gather, and λεχ, lay. —I. root λεγ, gather, collect, , , , , 224; count, ; pass., ; then enumerate, recount, tell, relate, , , ; mid., collect for oneself, count oneself in, select, , 547,, ; λέκτο ἀριθμόν, counted over the number (for himself), ; also talk over (with one another), μηκέτι ταῦτα λεγώμεθα, .—II. root λεχ, act. aor. 1, lay, put to bed or to rest, ; met., ; mid., fut. and aor. 1 and 2, lay oneself down, lie down to sleep, lie, , 453,, , .
λειαίνω (λεῖος), fut. λειανέω, aor. 3 pl. λείηναν, part. λειήνας: make smooth, smooth, level off, .
λείβω, ipf. λεῖβε, aor. inf. λεῖψαι: pour (in drops), shed, δάκρυα often; also esp., pour a libation, (οἶνον) τινί, or drink-offering; abs., . (See cut No. 77 on next page; cf. also Nos. 21 and 95.)
λεῖος (lēvis): smooth, even, level; πετράων, ‘free from rocks,’ .
λειριόεις, εσσα (λείριον): lily - like, lily-white, ; ὄψ, ‘delicate,’ . (Il.)
: son of Oenops, a suitor of Penelope and the soothsayer of the suitors; he shares their fate, , .
: (1) son of Arisbas, slain by Aenēas, .—(2) son of Euēnor, a suitor of Penelope, slain by Telemachus, , .
λείουσι: see λέων.
λεϊστός: see ληϊστός.
λέκτο: see λέγω.
: a promontory on the Trojan coast, opposite Lesbos, .
λέκτρον (root λεχ): bed, freq. the pl.; λέκτρονδε, .
λελαβέσθαι, λελάβῃσι: see λαμβάνω.
λελάθῃ, λελάθοντο: see λανθάνω.
λελακυῖα: see λάσκω.
λέλασμαι: see λανθάνω.
λελάχητε, λελάχωσι: see λαγχάνω.
: a piratical tribe on the south and west coast of Asia Minor, , .
λεληκώς: see λάσκω.
λελίημαι: only part., λελιημένος, as adj., eager, desirous; w. ὄφρα, *δ 465, . Cf. λιλαίομαι. (Il.)
λέλογχα: see λαγχάνω.
λέξεο, λέξο: see λέγω.
: a Lapith, the son of Corōnus, a suitor of Helen, , .
λέπαδνον, pl. λέπαδνα: breast-collar, a strap passing around the breast of the horses, and made fast to the yoke, . (See g in cut No. 78 below, also cut No. 45, f.）
λεπταλέος (λεπτός): fine, delicate, †.
λεπτός (λέπω), sup. λεπτότατος: peeled, husked, ; then thin, fine, narrow, delicate.
λέπω, aor. ἔλεψεν: peel, strip off; φύλλα, †.
: Lesbos, the island opposite the gulf of Adramyttium, , , from Lesbos, : Lesbian woman, , 271.
λέσχη: inn, tavern, †.
λευγαλέος (cf. λυγρός, λοιγός): mournful, miserable.—Adv., λευγαλέως, .
λευκαίνω: make white, with foam, †.
: πέτρη, ‘White rock,’ at the entrance of the nether world, on the border of Oceanus, †.
λεύκ-ασπις, ιδος: with white shield, white-shielded, †.
: Leucothea, a sea-goddess, once Ino, the daughter of Cadmus, , 461.
λευκός: clear, i. e. transparent or full of light, as water, the surface of water, or the radiance of the sky, , , ; then white, as snow, milk, bones, barley, , , , .
: a companion of Odysseus, †.
λευκ - ώλενος (ὠλένη, elbow, forearm): white - armed; epithet of goddesses and women according to the metrical convenience of their names; ἀμφίπολος, δμωαί, ς 198, .
λευρός: level, †.
λεύσσω (cf. λευκός, lux), ipf. λεῦσσε: see, behold.
λεχε-ποίης (λέχος, ποίη): with grassy bed (of a river); grassy (of towns), , .
λέχος, εος (root λεχ, λέγω): bed, bedstead, also pl. in both senses; typical in connubial relations, λέχος ἀντιᾶν, πορσύνειν, *α 31, ; funeralcouch, bier, , ; λέχοσδε, to the bed, .
λέων, οντος, dat. pl. λείουσι and λέουσι: lion; fig., where we should expect ‘lioness,’ .
λήγω, inf. ληγέμεναι, ipf. λῆγ̓, fut. λήξω, aor. 3 pl. λῆξαν: leave off, cease, w. gen. or w. part., , ; trans., abate, μένος,; χεῖρας φόνοιο, ‘stay’ my hands from slaughter, .
: Leda, the wife of Tyndareus, mother by Zeus of Helen, Castor, and Polydeuces, and of Clytaemnestra by Tyndareus, , 300.
ληθάνω: cause to forget, τινός, †.
λήθη: forgetfulness, oblivion, †.
: son of Teutamus, and father of Hippothous, , .
λήθω: see λανθάνω.
ληιάς, άδος: captive, †.
ληι - βότειρα (λήιον, βόσκω): cropeating, crop-destroying, †.
ληίζομαι, fut. ληίσσομαι, aor. ληίσσατο: carry off as booty.
λήιον: crop, grain still standing in the field, field of grain.
ληίς, ίδος: booty, prey.
ληιστήρ, ῆρος (ληίζομαι): buccaneer, rover, pl. (Od.)
ληιστός: to be plundered or taken by plundering, see ἑλετός.
ληίστωρ, ορος = ληιστήρ, †.
ληῖτις, ιδος: booty - bringing, giver of booty, epith. of Athēna, †.
: son of Alectryon, a leader of the Boeotians, , , , .
λήκυθος: oil-flask, and 215.

: Lemnos, the island west of the Troad, with probably in Homer's time a city of the same name, , 281; called ἠγαθέη, as sacred to Hephaestus (also to the Cabīri) on account of its volcano, Moschylus; now Stalimene [(ἐ）ς τὴ（ν) ].
λήσω: see λανθάνω.
: Leto (Latona), mother of Apollo and Artemis, , ; epith., ἐρικυδής, ἠύκομος, καλλιπάρῃος.
λιαρός: warm, lukewarm; αἷμα, ὕδωρ, *λ 477, ; then mild, gentle, , .
: Libya, west of Egypt, , .
λίγα (λιγύς): adv., clear, loudly, ἀείδειν, κωκύειν.
λιγαίνω (λιγύς): cry with clear, loud voice, †.
λίγγω, aor. λίγξε: twang, †.
λιγέως: see λιγύς.
λιγυ-πνείων, οντος: loudly blowing, whistling, †.
λιγυρός (λιγύς): clear-toned, whistling, piping; ἀοιδή, μάστιξ, πνοιαί,, , .

λιγύς, λιγεῖα, λιγύ: clear and loud of tone, said of singers, the harp, an orator, ‘clear-voiced,’ ‘clear-toned,’ , , ; of the wind, ‘piping,’ ‘whistling,’ , .—Adv., λιγέως, ἀγορεύειν, φυσᾶν, κλαίειν,, , .
λιγύ-φθογγος: loud-voiced, clearvoiced.
λιγύ-φωνος: with loud, clear note, of a falcon, †.
λίζω: see λίγγω.

λίην: too, excessively, greatly, very; μή τι λίην προκαλίζεο, provoke me not ‘too far,’ ; οὐδέ τι λίην οὕτω νώνυμός ἐστι, not so very unrenowned, , cf. ; often καὶ λίην at the beginning of a statement, ‘most certainly,’ ‘ay, by all means,’ etc.
λίθαξ, ακος: stony, hard, †.
λιθάς, άδος, dat. pl. λιθάδεσσι = λίθος. (Od.)
λίθεος: of stone.
λίθος, usually m.: stone, rock; fig. as symbol of firmness, or of harshness, , .
λικμάω (λικμός), part. gen. plur. λικμώντων: winnow, †.
λικμητήρ, ῆρος: winnower, who threw the grain with his winnowingshovel against the wind, thus separating it from the chaff, †.
λικριφίς: adv., sideways, to one side, and .
: brother of Alcmēna, slain by Tlepolemus, †.
: a town in Phocis, at the source of the Cephissus, †.
λιλαίομαι, ipf. λιλαίετο: desire, be desirous of or eager for, τινός, ; freq. w. inf.; with the inf. omitted, ; metaph., of the lance, λιλαιομένη χροὸς ἆσαι. Cf. λελίημαι.
λιμήν, ένος (cf. λείβω, λίμνη): harbor; pl. also in signif. of inlets, bays, , , .
λίμνη (cf. λείβω, λιμήν): lake, pond, even of a swamp or a marsh, ; also of the sea, .
(‘Harbor Ward’): a Nereid, †.
λιμός: hunger, famine.
: a town in Rhodes. †.
λινο - θώρηξ: with linen cuirass, . (As represented in adjoining cut, No. 79; cf. also No. 12.)
λίνον: flax, then anything made of it, thread, yarn, esp. fishing - line, ; of a fisher's net, ; linen cloth, linen, ; fig., of the thread of destiny, , , . (See cuts under ἠλακάτη.)
λίνος: lay of Linus, the Linus-song, an ancient popular melody, †.
λίπα: adv., always λίπ' ἐλαίῳ, richly with olive oil; but if the word is really an old dat., then with olive oil, ἐλαίῳ being adj.
λιπαρο - κρήδεμνος: with shining head-band, †.
λιπαρο - πλόκαμος: with shining locks or braids, †.
λιπαρός (λίπα): sleek, shining with ointment, ; shining (nitidus), ; then fig., rich, comfortable, θέμιστες, γῆρας, *ι 156, .—Adv., λιπαρῶς, fig., .
λιπόω: be sleek, v. l., †.
λίς (1), acc. λῖν: lion, , 480.
λίς (2) (λισσός): smooth, sheer, πέτρη, and 79.
λίς (3), dat. λιτί, acc. λῖτα: linen cloth, used as cover for a seat, ; or for a chariot when not in use, ; also as shroud for the dead, ; and to cover a cinerary urn, .

λίσσομαι (λιτή), ipf. (ἐ)(λ）λίσσετο, iter. λισσέσκετο, aor. 1 ἐλλισάμην, imp. λίσαι, aor. 2 ἐλιτόμην, inf. λιτέσθαι: pray, beseech with prayer; abs., , , and τινὰ εὐχῇσι, εὐχωλῇσι λιτῆσί τε, *ζηνός, ‘in the name of Zeus’; πρός, ὑπέρ τινος, γούνων (λαβών, ἁψάμενος), etc.; foll. by inf., sometimes ὅπως or ἵνα,, 237, ; with two accusatives, , cf. .
λισσός: smooth, sheer, πέτρη. (Od.)
λιστρεύω (λίστρον): dig about, †.
λίστρον: hoe or scraper, used in cleaning the floor of a hall, †.
λῖτα: see λί.
λιτανεύω (λιτή), ipf. ἐλλιτάνευε, λιτάνευε, fut. λιτανεύσομεν, aor. ἐλλιτάνευσα: pray, implore, abs., and w. acc., , .
λιτί: see λί.
λό̓: see λούω.
λοβός: lobe of the ear, pl. †.
λόγος (λέγω): tale, story, as entertaining recital, with enumeration of details, pl., and .
λόε, λοέσσαι, λοεσσάμενος: see λούω.
λοετρόν (λοϝετρόν, λούω): bathing, bath, pl., , ‘in Ocean,’ .
λοετρο - χοός (χέω): pouring (containing) water for the bath, τρίπος, tripod with water - kettle, , ; subst., bath-maid, .
λοέω: see λούω.
λοιβή (λείβω): libation.
λοίγιος (λοιγός): destructive, ruinous, deadly; as subst., , . (Il.)
λοιγός: destruction, ruin, death, by sickness (pestilence) or war. (Il.)
λοιμός: pestilence, and 97.
λοισθήιος (λοῖσθος): for the last in the race, only of prizes, ἄεθλον; and as subst. λοισθήια (cf. πρωτεῖα, δευτερεῖα), prize for the last, . (Il.)
λοῖσθος (λοιπός): last, †.
: the Locrians, a tribe occupying one of the divisions of Hellas, and dwelling on the Eurīpus, on both sides of Mt. Cnemis, , 535, .
λοπός (λέπω): peel, skin, †.

λούω, λοέω (cf. lavo), ipf. λοῦον, λό̓ (λόϝε), aor. λοῦς（εν), subj. λούσῃ, imp. λόεσον, λούσατε, inf. λοέσαι, part. λοέσασα, mid. pres. inf. λούεσθαι, λοῦσθαι, fut. λοέσσομαι, aor. λοέσσατο, λούσαντο, etc., pass. perf. part. λελουμένος: bathe, wash, mid., bathe, get washed.; fig., of the rising of Sirius, λελουμένος *̓ωκεανοῖο, ‘after his bath in Ocean,’ .
λοφιή (λόφος): the bristly ridge or comb of a wild boar's back, †.

λόφος: (1) crest or plume of a helmet, usually of horse - hair, . (See adjoining cuts, and Nos. 3, 11, 12, 16, 17, 35, 73, 116, 122.)—(2) back of the neck of animals or of men, , .—(3) hill, ridge. (Od.)
λοχάω (λόχος), aor. inf. λοχῆσαι, mid. fut. λοχήσομαι, aor. part. λοχησάμενος: act. and mid., lie in ambush, lie in wait for, waylay, τινά, .
λόχμη (root λεχ): lair of a wild beast, thicket, jungle, †.

λόχος (root λεχ): place of ambush, act of lying in wait; said of the Trojan horse, , ; also of the party forming the ambuscade, ; and of any armed company, ; λόχος γέροντος, ‘means of entrapping’ the old man of the sea, : upon an ambuscade, into the ambush, , .
λύγος: willow-twig, osier, withe.
λυγρός (cf. λευγαλέος): sad, mournful, miserable; in apparently active sense, φάρμακα, σήματα, etc., , ; also fig., and in derogatory sense, ‘sorry,’ εἵματα, ; so of persons, .—Adv., λυγρῶς.
λύθεν: see λύω.
λύθρον: properly pollution, then gore (or blood mixed with dust), with and without αἷμα.
λυκά - βας, αντος (root λυκ, lux, βαίνω): year, and .
: a town in the southern part of Crete, .
: (1) a Lycian, the father of Pandarus, , 95.—(2) son of Priam and Laothoe, slain by Achilles, ff.
λυκέη: wolf-skin, †.
λυκη - γενής, έος (root λυκ, lux): light-born, epith. of Apollo as sun-god, , 119.
: Lycia.—(1) a division of Asia Minor, .—(2) a district on the river Aesēpus, its chief town Zeleia, , , from Lycia, , to Lycia, .
: the Lycians, inhabitants of Lycia (1). Led by Glaucus and by Sarpēdon, , , , .
: son of Creon in Boeotia, , .
(.): Lycurgus.— (1) son of Dryas, king of the Edonians in Thrace, banishes from his land the worship of Dionȳsus (Bacchus), . —(2) an Arcadian, slays Arithous, -148.
λύκος (ϝλύκος): wolf; symbol of bloodthirstiness, , .
: a Trojan, slain by Teucer, .
: son of Mastor, from Cythēra, a companion of Ajax, .
: a city in Crete, east of Cnosus, , .
: a Trojan, slain by Peneleüs, , 337.
λῦμα, pl. λύματα: anything washed away, defilement, ; in symbolical and ritualistic sense, offerings of purification, .
λυπρός: sorry, poor, †.
: Lyrnessus, a town in Mysia, under the sway of Hypoplacian Thebes, , , , 191.
: a Trojan, slain by Ajax, †.
λυσι-μελής, ές (λύω, μέλος): relaxing the limbs, ὕπνος, (with a play upon the word in v. 56).
λύσις, ιος (λύω): loosing, ransoming, ; θανάτου, ‘deliverance’ from death, .
λύσσα: martial rage. (Il.)
λυσσητήρ, ῆρος: one who rages, raging, w. κύων, †.
λυσσώδης (εἶδος): raging, †.
λύχνος: light, lamp, †.

λύω, ipf. ἔλυον, λύε, fut. λύσω, aor. ἔλυσα, λῦσεν, mid. aor. ἐλύσαο, inf. λύσασθαι, aor. 2, w. pass. signif., λύτο, λύντο, pass. perf. λέλυμαι, opt. λελῦτο, aor. λύθη, 3 pl. λύθεν: I. act., loose, loosen, set free, of undoing garments, ropes, , , ; unharnessing horses, ; of freeing from bonds or captivity (said of the captor), ; pass., of anything giving way, coming apart, , ; fig., in senses answering to those enumerated, τινὰ κακότητος, ‘deliver’ from misery; ἀγορήν, ‘dismiss’; so λύτο δ' ἀγών; and with reference to emotion, or fainting, death, λύτο γούνατα καὶ φίλον ἦτορ, ‘gave way,’ ‘sank,’ ‘quaked’ (sometimes the act., ); of sleep ‘relaxing’ the limbs, or ‘dissolving’ cares, , ; of ‘undoing’ (destroying) cities, .—III. mid., loose or undo oneself, , or something of one's own, get loosed or released, ransom; λυσόμενος θύγατρα, said of the father, ; cf. the act., v. 20.
λωβάομαι (λώβη), aor. imp. λωβήσασθε, opt. λωβήσαιο: maltreat, outrage; w. cognate acc. and obj. τινὰ λώβην, do despite, .
λωβεύω: mock, and 26.
λώβη: outrage, insult; σοὶ λώβη, ‘shame upon thee,’ if, etc., ; of a person, ‘object of ignominy,’ .
λωβητήρ, ῆρος: one who outrages or insults, slanderer, scoundrel, , . (Il.)
λωβητός: maltreated, outraged, †.
λώϊον, λωΐτερον: better, preferable; ‘more liberally,’ .
λώπη (λέπω): mantle, †.
λωτοῦντα (λωτός), either a part., or adj., for λωτόεντα: full of lotus, ‘clovery,’ πεδία, †.

λωτός: lotus.—(1) a species of clover, , .—(2) the tree and fruit enjoyed by the Lotus-eaters, ff. Said to be a plant with fruit the size of olives, in taste resembling dates, still prized in Tunis and Tripoli under the name of Jujube.
: the Lotus-eaters, ff.
λωφάω, fut. λωφήσει, aor. opt. λωφήσειε: rest from, cease from, retire, , .

div1.head: *m
div1.entryFree: μ̓: usually for μέ, sometimes for μοί, *ζ 165, , etc.
μά: by, in oaths, w. acc. of the divinity or of the witness invoked; mostly neg., w. οὐ, ; sometimes, w. ναί, affirmative, .
: a Thessalian tribe, sprung from Aeolus, .
μαζός: nipple, pap, then mother's breast.
μαῖα (cf. μήτηρ): voc., used esp. in addressing the old nurse, ‘good mother,’ ‘aunty,’ , .
, άδος: Maia, daughter of Atlas, and mother of Hermes, †.
: the Maeander, the river of many windings that flows into the sea near Milētus, †.
: son of Maemalus, Pisander, †.
μαιμάω, μαιμώωσι, part. μαιμώωσα, aor. μαίμησα: strive or desire madly, rage; fig., αἰχμή, .
μαινάς, άδος (μαίνομαι): madwoman, †.
μαίνομαι, ipf. μαίνετο: be mad, rave, rage, , ; often of the frenzy of battle, , ; fig., of the hand, weapons, fire, , , .
μαίομαι, inf. μαίεσθαι, part. μαιομένη: seek for, explore, , ; μάσσεται, ‘will find’ a wife for me (γὲ μάσσεται, Aristarchus' reading for vulg. γαμέσσεται), .
: (1) a Nereid, .—(2) an attendant of Artemis, mother of Locrus, .
: son of Haemon in Thebes, , 398.
μάκαρ, αρος, sup. μακάρτατος: blessed, blest, of gods, , and without θεοί, ; of men, blissful, happy, through wealth or otherwise, , .
: son of Aeolus, ruling in Lesbos, †.
μακαρίζω: pronounce happy. (Od.)
μακεδνός (cf. μακρός): tall, †.
μάκελλα: mattock, †.

μακρός, comp. μακρότερος and μᾶσσον, sup. μακρότατος: long, tall, of space and of time (κέλευθος, ἤματα), and of things that are high or deep (οὔρεα, δένδρα, φρείατα, ); freq. adv., μακρόν, μακρά, far, afar, βοᾶν, ἀυτεῖν; μακρὰ βιβάς, ‘with long strides.’
μακών: see μηκάομαι.

μάλα, comp. μᾶλλον, sup. μάλιστα: (1) positive, μάλα, very, quite, right, modifying adjectives and other adverbs, and sometimes placed after its word, ἦρι μάλ̓, ; occasionally with substantives, μάλα χρεώ, *ι 197, ; also with verbs (μάλα πολεμίζειν, ‘with might and main’), and esp. to strengthen an assertion as a whole, certainly, verily, . μάλα admits of much variety in translating in connection with its several usages.—(2) comp., μᾶλλον, more, all the more, ; ‘more willingly,’ ‘more gladly,’ , .—(3) sup., μάλιστα, most, especially, far, by far, with adjectives forming a superlative, ; and even with superlatives themselves, f., .
μαλακός, comp. μαλακώτερος: soft, and metaph., mild, gentle; θάνατος, ὕπνος,, ς 202, .—Adv., μαλακῶς.
: Malea, southern promontory of the Peloponnesus, , , .
μαλερός: powerful, destroying, epith. of fire. (Il.)
μαλθακός = μαλακός, fig. effeminate, cowardly, †.
μάλιστα, μᾶλλον: see μάλα.
μάν (= μήν): verily, truly, indeed; ἄγρει μάν, ‘come now!’ ἦ μάν, οὐ μάν, μὴ μάν,, , , .
μανθάνω, only aor. μάθον, ἔμμαθες: learn, come to know, τὶ, and w. inf., .
μαντεύομαι (μάντις), ipf. μαντεύετο, fut. μαντεύσομαι: declare oracles, divine, prophesy, .
μαντήιον: oracle, prophecy, pl., †.
: a city in Arcadia, †.
: son of Melampus, and brother of Antiphates, , 249.

μάντις, ιος (μάντηος, ): seer, prophet, expounder of omens, which were drawn from the flight of birds, from dreams, and from sacrifices. Seers celebrated by Homer are Tiresias, Calchas, Melampus, Theoclymenus.
μαντοσύνη: the art or gift of divination, prophecy; pl., .
μάομαι: see μαίομαι.
(μάραθον, ‘fennel’): a village in Attica, †.
μαραίνομαι, ipf. ἐμαραίνετο, aor. ἐμαράνθη: of fire, die gradually away. (Il.)
μαργαίνω (μάργος): rage madly or wildly, †.
μάργος: mad, raving, raging. (Od.)
: a Lycian, son of Amisodarus, .
μαρμαίρω: sparkle, flash, glitter.
μαρμάρεος: flashing, glittering. (Il.)
μαρμαρυγή (μαρμαρύσσω = μαρμαίρω): the quick twinkling of dancers' feet, pl., †.
μάρναμαι, opt. μαρνοίμεθα, inf. μάρνασθαι, ipf. ἐμαρνάσθην: fight; also contend, wrangle, .
: daughter of Euēnus, and wife of Idas, who recovered her after she had been carried off by Apollo, ff.
μάρπτω, ipf. ἔμαρπτε, μάρπτε, fut. μάρψω, aor. ἔμαρψα: seize, lay hold of, overtake; of reaching or touching with the feet, ; inflicting a stroke (κεραυνός), , 419; fig., of sleep, age, , .
μαρτυρίη: testimony, pl., †.
μάρτυρος: witness.
: son of Euanthes, priest of Apollo in Ismarus, †.
: a town in Argolis, near Hermione, †.
μάσσεται: see μαίομαι.
μᾶσσον: see μακρός.
μάσταξ, ακος (μαστάζω, chew): mouth; a mouthful of food, .
μαστίζω: use the μάστιξ, lash, whip.
μάστιξ, ῖγος, and μάστις, dat. μάστι, acc. μάστιγα, μάστιν: whip, scourge; fig., , .
μαστίω = μαστίζω, mid., .
: son of Mastor.—(1) Halitherses in Ithaca, , .— (2) Lycophron, , 430.
ματάω (μάτην), aor. ἐμάτησεν, subj. du. ματήσετον: do in vain, fail, ; then be idle, delay, linger.
ματεύω, fut. ματεύσομεν: seek, †.
ματίη (μάτην): fruitless toil, †.
μάχαιρα: dagger, knife for sacrificing, broad and short in shape. (Il.) (See the cut, and No. 109.)
: Machāon, one of the sons of Asclepius, ruler in Tricca and Ithōme in Thessaly, distinguished in the art of healing, , 613, *δ 200, ; wounded by Hector, , 598, 651.
μαχειόμενος, μαχεούμενον: see μάχομαι.
μάχη: flight, battle, combat; μάχην μάχεσθαι, τίθεσθαι, στήσασθαι, ὀρνύμεν, ἐγείρειν, ὀτρύνειν, ἀρτύνειν, συμφέρεσθαι: of single combat, and ; for the field of battle, .
μαχήμων: warlike, †.
μαχητής: fighter, warrior.
μαχητός: that may be vanquished, †.
μαχλοσύνη (μάχλος): lust, indulgence, †.

μάχομαι, μαχέομαι, opt. μαχέοιτο, -οίατο (, 344), part. μαχειόμενος, μαχεούμενος, ipf. (ἐ）μαχόμην, iter. μα- χέσκετο, fut. μαχήσομαι, μαχέσσομαι, μαχεῖται, μαχέονται, aor. inf. μαχήσασθαι, μαχέσασθαι: fight, contend, usually in war, including single combat, but sometimes of friendly contest, ; and of wrangling, quarrelling with words, etc., , , .
μάψ, μαψιδίως: rashly (temere), in vain, ; wantonly, , , cf. , , .
: son of Megas, Perimus, †.
μεγά - θυμος: great - hearted, highhearted, high-spirited, epith. of nations, Athēna, a bull.
μεγαίρω (μέγας), aor. μέγηρε, subj. μεγήρῃς: properly, to regard something as too great, grudge, begrudge, hence, refuse, object; with acc.; also part. gen., ; and foll. by inf., .
μεγα-κήτης, ες (κῆτος): with great gulf or hollow; δελφίν, ‘voracious,’ ; νηῦς, ‘wide-bellied,’ ; πόντος, ‘wide-yawning,’ .
μεγαλ-ήτωρ (ἦτορ): great - hearted, proud.
μεγαλίζομαι: exalt oneself, be proud. (Il. and .)
μεγάλως: see μέγας.
μεγαλωστί: μέγας μεγαλωστί, ‘great in his (thy) greatness,’ of a stately form prostrate upon the earth, , , .
(‘Mournful,’ from the deserted father): Megapenthes, son of Menelāus by a slave, , 103, .
: Megara, daughter of Creon in Thebes, wife of Heracles, †.

μέγαρον (μέγας): properly large room.—(1) the men's dining-hall, the chief room of the Homeric house. The roof was supported by columns, the light entered through the doors, the smoke escaped by an opening overhead and through loop - holes (ὀπαῖα) just under the roof. The cut, combined from different ancient representations, is designed to show the back part of the μέγαρον in the house of Odysseus, cf. plate III. for groundplan.—(2) the women's apartment, behind the one just described, see plate III. G. Pl., .—(3) the housekeeper's apartment in the upper story (ὑπερώιον), .—(4) a sleeping-apartment, .—(5) in wider signif., in pl., house, .

μέγας, μεγάλη, μέγα, comp. μείζων, sup. μέγιστος: great, large, of persons, tall (καλός τε μέγας τε, καλή τε μεγάλη τε, *φ 108, ); of things with reference to any kind of dimension, and also to power, loudness, etc., ἄνεμος, ἰαχή, ὀρυμαγδός; in unfavorable sense, μέγα ἔργον (facinus), so μέγα ἔπος, μέγα φρονεῖν, εἰπεῖν, ‘be proud,’ ‘boast,’ , .—Adv., μεγάλως, also μέγα, μεγάλα, greatly, exceedingly, aloud, etc.
μέγεθος, εος: stature, height; see μέγας, third definition.
: son of Phyleus and of the sister of Odysseus, chief of the inhabitants of Dulichium and the Echinades, , , , 535, *β 627, .
μέγιστος: see μέγας.
μεδέων: ruling, bearing sway, only of Zeus. (Il.)
: a town in Boeotia, †.
μέδομαι, fut. μεδήσομαι: be mindful of, bethink oneself of; δόρποιο, κοίτου, ἀλκῆς, *ς 245, ; also devise, κακά τινι, *δ 21, .
μέδων, οντος (μέδομαι): ἁλός, ruler of the sea, ; pl., ἡγήτορες ἠδὲ μέδοντες, counsellors.
: (1) son of Oī¨leus, stepbrother of Ajax, from Phylace, chief of the warriors from Methōne in Phthia, , 695 ff., ; slain by Aenēas, .—(2) a Lycian, .—(3) a herald in Ithaca, , , , 361, .
μεθ-αιρέω: only aor. iter. μεθέλεσκε, would reach after and catch, i. e. ‘on the fly,’ .
μεθ-άλλομαι: only aor. part., μετάλμενος, springing after or upon a person or thing, overtaking. (Il.)
μεθείω: see μεθίημι.
μεθέλεσκε: see μεθαιρέω.
μεθέμεν: see μεθίημι.

μεθ - έπω, ipf. μέθεπε, aor. 2 part. μετασπών, mid. μετασπόμενος: move after, follow after, follow up; trans., w. two accusatives, ἵππους *τυδείδην, turn the steeds after Tydīdes, ; of ‘visiting’ a place, ; mid., .
μέθ-ημαι: only part., μεθήμενος, sitting among, †.
μεθ-ημοσύνη: remissness, and 121.
μεθ-ήμων (μεθίημι): remiss, careless.

μεθ - ίημι, μεθίεις, μεθίει (-ιεῖς, ιεῖ), inf. μεθιέμεν（αι), subj. μεθιῇσι (-ίῃσι), ipf. μεθίεις, μεθίει (-ίης, -ίη), 3 pl. μέθιεν, μεθίεσαν, fut. μεθήσω, aor. μεθέηκα, μεθῆκεν, subj. μεθείω, μεθείῃ, μεθήῃ, μεθῶμεν, inf. μεθέμεν, μεθεῖναι: let go after or among.—(1) trans., of letting a person go away, or go free, , ; letting a thing go (ἐς ποταμόν), ; give up, give over, , , and w. inf., ; metaph., in the above senses, μεθέμεν χόλον, ‘dismiss,’ ; εἴ με μεθείη ῥῖγος, . —(2) intrans., relax effort, be remiss, abs., , ; w. gen., desist from, neglect, cease, , ; w. part. or inf., , .
μεθ-ίστημι, fut. μεταστήσω, mid. ipf. μεθίστατο: substitute, i. e. exchange, ; mid., stand over among, ‘retire’ among, .
μεθ - ομιλέω: associate with, have dealings with, ipf., †.
μεθ - ορμάομαι: only aor. part., μεθορμηθείς, starting after, ‘making a dash after.’
μέθυ, υος (cf. ‘mead’): strong drink, wine.
μεθύω (μέθυ): be drunken, fig., soaked, .
μειδάω (root σμι), μειδιάω, part. μειδιόων, -όωσα, aor. μείδησα: smile.
μείζων: see μέγας.
μείλανι: see μέλας.
μείλια: soothing gifts, gifts of reconciliation, and 289.
μείλιγμα, ατος (μειλίσσω): that which soothes, μειλίγματα θυμοῦ, things to appease the appetite, tid - bits, †.
μείλινος: see μέλινος.
μειλίσσω, inf. μειλισσέμεν, mid. imp. μειλίσσεο: appease the dead with fire (πυρός, cf. constr. w. λαγχάνειν), ; mid., ‘extenuate,’ (‘try to make it pleasant’ for me).
μειλιχίη: mildness, i. e. ‘feebleness,’ πολέμοιο, †.
μειλίχιος and μείλιχος: mild, pleasant, gentle, winsome, .

μείρομαι (root μερ, μορ), ipf. 2 sing. μείρεο, perf. ἔμμορε, pass. plup. εἵμαρτο: cause to be divided, receive as a portion, ipf. w. acc., ; perf. w. gen., share, , , ; pass., εἵμαρτο, it was ordained, decreed by fate, , , .
μείς, μήν, μηνός: month, .
μείων: see μικρός.
μελαγ - χροιής, ές: dark - skinned, swarthy, ‘bronzed,’ †.

μέλαθρον, μελαθρόφι: beam, crossbeam of a house, supporting rafters and roof; these beams passed through the wall and projected externally, hence ἐπὶ προὔχοντι μελάθρῳ, ; then roof (tectum), and in wider sense dwelling, mansion, .
μελαίνω (μέλας): only mid., become dark, grow dark, of blood-stains, and of the glebe under the plough, and .

: Melampus, son of Amythāon, a famous seer in Pylus. Undertaking to fetch from Phylace in Thessaly the cattle of Iphiclus, and thus to win the hand of Pero for his brother Bias, he was taken captive, as he had himself predicted, and held prisoner for one year, when in consequence of good counsel given by him he was set free by Iphiclus, gained his end, and settled in Argos, ff., ff.
μελάν-δετος (δέω): black - bound or mounted, i. e. with dark hilt or scabbard, †.
: father of Amphimedon in Ithaca, .
or : Melanthius, son of Dolius, goat-herd on the estate of Odysseus, of insolent disposition, , , , ff., 182.
: (1) see .— (2) a Trojan, slain by Eurypylus, .
: Melantho, sister of Melanthius (1), and of the same stripe, , .
: (1) an Achaean chief, .—(2) a Trojan, son of Hicetāon, slain by Antiochus, -582.—(3) a Trojan, slain by Teucer, .—(4) a Trojan, slain by Patroclus, .
μελανό-χροος and μελανό-χρως, οος: dark-skinned, black, and .
μελάν-υδρος: of dark water, κρήνη.
μελάνω: grow black, darken, † (v. l. μελανεῖ).

μέλας, μέλαινα, μέλαν, dat. μείλανι, comp. μελάντερος: dark, black, in the general and extensive meaning of these words, opp. λευκός, ; said of dust, steel, blood, wine, water, grapes, ships, clouds, evening, night, death.—As subst., μέλαν δρυός, i. e. the ‘heart-wood,’ which is always the darkest, .
: son of Portheus, †.

(ᾧ μέλει ἄγρα): Meleāger, son of Oeneus and Althaea, husband of Cleopatra, the slayer of the Calydonian boar. A quarrel arose between the Curētes of Pleuron and the Aetolians for the head and skin of the boar. The Aetolians had the upper hand until Meleāger withdrew from the struggle in consequence of the curses of his mother. But he was afterwards induced by his wife to enter the conflict again, and he drove the Curētes vanquished into Acarnania, ff., .
μελέδημα, ατος (μέλω): care, anxiety, only pl.
μελεδών, ῶνος (μέλω) = μελέδημα, † (v. l. μελεδῶναι).
μέλει: see μέλω.
μελεϊστί (μέλος): adv., limb - meal, limb by limb, , , .
μέλεος: fruitless, idle, unrewarded, neut. as adv., in vain, .
μέλι, ιτος: honey; used even as a drink, mixed with wine; burned upon the funeral-pyre, , ; mixed with milk in drink-offerings, μελίκρητον. Figuratively, , .
: a town in Magnesia, †.
μελί - γηρυς: honey - toned, sweetvoiced, †.
μελίη: the ash-tree, , ; then of the shaft of the lance, lance, freq. w. , ‘from Mt. Pelion’; other epithets, εὔχαλκος, χαλκογλώχιν.
μελι-ηδής, ές: honey-sweet; fig., ὕπνος, νόστος, θυμός.
μελί - κρητον (κεράννυμι): honeymixture, honey - drink, a potion compounded of milk and honey for libation to the shades of the nether world, , .
μέλινος, μείλινος (μελίη): ashen. (Il.)
μέλισσα (μέλι): bee.
: a Nereid, †.
μελί - φρων: honey - minded, honeylike, sweet.

μέλλω, ipf. ἔμελλον, μέλλε: be going or about to do something, foll. by fut. inf., sometimes pres., rarely aor., ; μέλλω never means to intend, although intention is of course sometimes implied, τῇ γὰρ ἔμελλε διεξίμεναι πεδίονδε, ‘for by that gate he was going to pass out,’ ; by destiny as it were, of something that was or was not meant to happen, | ἔδμεναι, ‘you were not going to eat the comrades of a man unable to defend himself after all,’ i. e. he was no coward whose companions you undertook to eat, and therefore it was not meant that you should eat them with impunity, , and often similarly. Virtually the same is the usage that calls for must in paraphrasing, οὕτω που *διὶ μέλλει ὑπερμενέϊ φίλον εἶναι, such methinks ‘must’ be the will of Zeus; τὰ δὲ μέλλετ' ἀκουέμεν, ye ‘must’ have heard, , , , ; μέλλει μέν πού τις καὶ φίλτερον ἄλλον ὀλέσσαι, ‘may well’ have lost, .
μέλος, εος: limb, member, only pl.
μέλπω: act., celebrate with dance and song, ; mid., play (and sing), φορμίζων, on the lyre, , ; dance and sing, ἐν χορῷ, ; fig., μέλπεσθαι *̓́αρηι, .

μέλω, μέλει, μέλουσι, imp. μελέτω, μελόντων, inf. μελέμεν, ipf. ἔμελε, μέλε, fut. μελήσει, inf. μελησέμεν, perf. μέμηλεν, subj. μεμήλῃ, part. μεμηλώς, plup. μεμήλει, mid. pres. imp. μελέσθω, fut. μελήσεται, perf. μέμβλεται, plup. μέμβλετο: be an object of care or interest; πᾶσι δόλοισι | ἀνθρώποισι μέλω, i. e. my wiles give me a world - wide ‘renown,’ ; cf. , i. e. the Argo ‘all - renowned,’ ; mostly only the 3d pers., μέλει μοί τις or τὶ, ‘I care for,’ ‘am concerned with’ or ‘in’ somebody or something, he, she, or it ‘interests me,’ ‘rests’ or ‘weighs upon my mind’; μελήσουσί μοι ἵπποι, ‘I will take care of the horses,’ ; ἀνὴρ ᾧ τόσσα μέμηλεν, who has so many ‘responsibilities,’ ; perf. part. μεμηλώς, ‘interested’ or ‘engaged in,’ ‘intent on,’ τινός, *ε 708, ; mid., , , , .

μέμαα, perf. w. pres. signif., du. μέματον, pl. μέμαμεν, μέματε, μεμάασι, imp. μεμάτω, part. μεμαώς, μεμαυῖα, μεμαῶτος, μεμαότες, μεμαότε, plup. μέμασαν: be eagerly desirous, press on hotly, go impetuously at; ἐπί τινι, *θ 327, , abs. ; foll. by inf., even the fut., , ; freq. the part., as adj. (or adv.), hotly desirous or eager.
μεμακυῖα: see μηκάομαι.
μέμβλωκα: see βλώσκω.
μέμβλεται, μέμβλετο: see μέλω.
μεμηκώς: see μηκάομαι.
μέμηλα: see μέλω.
μεμνέῳτο, μεμνώμεθα: see μιμνήσκω.
: Memnon, son of Eos and Tithōnus, came to the aid of Priam after the death of Hector, and slew Antilochus, , cf. .

μέμονα, μέμονας, μέμονεν, perf. w. pres. signif.: have in mind, be minded, be impelled or prompted, w. inf., sometimes the fut., , ; μέμονεν δ' ὅ γε ἶσα θεοῖσι (cf. φρονέειν ἶσα), ‘vies with the gods,’ ; διχθα κραδίη μέμονε, ‘yearns with a twofold wish,’ in hesitation, .
μέμυκα: see μυκάομαι.

μέν (μήν): (1) the same as μήν, in truth, indeed, certainly, , , ; sometimes might be written μήν, as the scansion shows, , ; freq. to emphasize a pronoun or another particle, and of course not always translatable, τοῦ μέν, ἦ μέν, καὶ μέν, οὐ μέν, οὐδὲ μὲν οὐδέ, ζ 13, . —(2) in correlation, μέν without losing the force above described calls attention to what follows, the following statement being introduced by δέ, αὐτάρ, or some other adversative word. μέν in correlation may sometimes be translated to be sure (quidem), although, but oftener does not admit of translation. It should be remembered that μέν is never a connective, that it always looks forward, never backward. Its combinations with other particles are various.
μενεαίνω, inf. μενεαινέμεν, ipf. μενεαίνομεν, aor. μενεήναμεν: cagerly desire, w. inf., sometimes fut., and ; also be angered, strive, contend, , , .
μενε-δήιος (μένω): withstanding the enemy, steadfast, brave, and .

: Menelāus, son of Atreus and brother of Agamemnon, the successful suitor of Helen. King in Lacedaemon, a brave and spirited warrior, but not of the warlike temperament that distinguishes others of the Greeks before Troy above him, ff. After the war he wanders eight years before reaching home, ff. Epithets, ἀρήιος, ἀρηίφιλος, διοτρεφής, δουρικλειτός, κυδάλιμος, ξανθός.
μενε-πτόλεμος (μένω): steadfast in battle. (Il.)
: Menestheus, son of Peteos, leader of the Athenians, renowned as a chariot-fighter, , , , .
: a Greek, slain by Hector, †.
: (1) son of Areïthous, slain by Paris, .—(2) a Myrmidon, son of Spercheius, .
μενε-χάρμης and μενέ-χαρμος (μένω, χάρμη): steadfast or stanch in battle. (Il.)
μενο-εικής, ες (μένος, ϝείκω): suiting the spirit, i. e. grateful, satisfying; usually said with reference to quantity, plenty of, so pl. μενοεικέ, ; and w. πολλά, .
μενοινάω, μενοινέω, μενοινώω, subj. μενοινάᾳ, μενοινήῃσι, aor. 1 ἐμενοίνησα: have in mind, ponder (), intend, devise; φρεσί, μετὰ φρεσί, ἐνὶ θυμῷ, ὁδόν, νόστον, κακά τινι, .
: son of Menoetius, Patroclus, , , .
: Menoetius, son of Actor and father of Patroclus, an Argonaut, , , ff.

μένος, εος: impulse, will, spirit, might, courage, martial fury, rage (noble or otherwise), pl. μένεα πνείοντες, ‘breathing might,’ . A very characteristic Homeric word, with a wide range of application; joined w. θυμός, ἀλκή, θάρσος, ψυχή, χεῖρες, γυῖα, and w. gen. of names as periphrases for the person, , ; said of things as well as men and animals, wind, fire, the sun, etc.
: (1) leader of the Ciconians, .—(2) son of Anchialus, king of the Taphians, under whose form Athena visits Telemachus, , 180.
μέντοι: indeed, to be sure, however; see μέν and τοί.

: Mentor.—(1) an Ithacan, the son of Alcimus, a near friend of Odysseus, to whom Odysseus intrusts the oversight of his household during his absence. Under the form of Mentor, Athēna guides Telemachus on his travels in search of his father, and helps him to baffle the suitors; in other words she makes herself his mentor, , 243,, 340,, 208, .—(2) father of Imbrius, under whose form Apollo incites Hector to battle, .

μένω and μίμνω, ipf. iter. μένεσκον, fut. μενέω, aor. ἔμεινα, μεῖνα: remain, wait, and trans., await, withsland, , ; foll. by inf., ; εἰσόκε, ; freq. of standing one's ground in battle or elsewhere, , ; also w. obj., δόρυ, ἔγχος, etc.
: a Trojan, slain by Leonteus, †.
: son of Mermesus, Ilus, †.
: a Mysian, slain by Antilochus, †.

μερμηρίζω, aor. μερμήριξα: ponder, wonder, reflect, trans., think over, ; freq. w. δίχα, διάνδιχα, of a mind hesitating between two resolves, , ; foll. by ἤ (ἢ.. ἦ), also ὡς, ὅπως, and by inf., ; ‘imagine,’ , 261.
μέρμις, ῖθος: cord, †.
μέροψ, οπος: probably mortal, μέροπες ἄνθρωποι, μερόπεσσι βροτοῖσιν, *ς 288, .
: a seer and ruler in Percōte on the Hellespont, father of Adrastus and Amphīus, , .
μέρομαι: see μείρομαι.
μεσαι-πόλιος (μέσος, πολιός): halfgray, grizzled, †.
: a servant of Eumaeus, , 455.
μεσήεις (μέσος): middling, †.
: son of Talaemenes, leader of the Maeonians, , .

μεσόδμη (δέμω): properly something mid-built.—(1) mast-block, represented in the cut (see a) as a metal shoe in which the mast was firmly fastened so as to be turned back ward on the pivot (c) to a horizontal position, until it rested upon the ἱστοδόκη, . See also plate IV., where the μεσόδμη is somewhat differently represented as a threesided trough or mast-box.—(2) μεσόδμαι, small spaces or niches, opening into the μέγαρον of the house, and enclosed on three sides, behind by the outside wall, and on either side by the low walls which served as foundations of the columns, . (See plate III., γ, and cut No. 83.)

μέσος, μέσσος: in the middle of; μέσσῃ ἁλί, in mid-sea, ; ἥμενοι ἐν μέσσοισι, ‘in the midst of them,’ ; of time, μέσον ἦμαρ; as subst., μέσον, the middle; ἐς μέσον τιθέναι, ‘offer for competition,’ as prize, ; ἐς μέσον ἀμφοτέροις δικάζειν, ‘impartially,’ ; as adv., μέσον, in the middle, , .
μέσσατος (sup. to μέσος): in the very middle, and .
μέσσ-αυλος: mid-court, court, farmyard, ; cattle-yard, .
: a harbor-town near Taenarum in Laconia, †.
μεσσηγύς: see μεσηγύς.
: a spring in Thessalian Hellas, †.
: a district about Pherae in what was afterward Messenia, .
: the Messenians, inhabitants of Messēne, .
μεσσο - παγής, ές (πήγνυμι): fixed up to the middle; ἔθηκεν ἔγχος, drove the spear half its length firm into the bank, (v. l. μεσσοπαλές, ‘vibrating to the middle’).
μέσφα (=Att. μέχρι): till, until, w. gen., †.

μετά: amid, among, after.—I. adv. (here belong all instances of ‘tmesis’), μετὰ δ' ἰὸν ἕηκεν, let fly an arrow among them (the ships), , ; πρῶτος ἐγώ, μετὰ δ' ὔμμες, afterward, , and so of time, : denoting change of position, μετὰ δ' ἄστρα βεβήκει, ‘had passed over the meridian’; μετὰ δ' ἐτράπετ̓, ‘turned around’; μετὰ νῶτα βαλών,, , . The relation of the adv. may be specified by a case of a subst., thus showing the transition to the true prepositional use, μετὰ καὶ τόδε τοῖσι γενέσθω, ‘let this be added to those and be among them,’ .—II. prep., (1) w. gen., along with; μετ' ἄλλων λέξο ἑταίρων, μάχεσθαι μετά τινος, ‘in league with,’ , .—(2) w. dat., amid, among, between, in; μετὰ χερσὶν ἔχειν, ‘in the hands,’ , ; μετὰ γένυσσι, ποσσί, ‘between,’ , ; μετὰ πνοιῇς ἀνέμοιο πέτεσθαι, i. e. as fast as the winds, ; *οὖτιν ἐγὼ πύματον ἔδομαι μετὰ οἷς ἑτάροισιν, the last ‘among’ his mates, the position of honor in being eaten, .—(3) w. acc., denoting motion, among, towards, to, after, μετ' *αἰθιοπῆας ἔβη, μετὰ μῶλον *̓́αρηος, σφαῖραν ἔρριψε μετ̓ ἀμφίπολον, βῆναι μετά τινα,, , ζ 115, , and sometimes of course in a hostile sense; so fig., βάλλειν τινὰ μετ' ἔριδας, ‘plunge in,’ ‘involve in,’ ; sometimes only position, without motion, is denoted, ; of succession, after, next to, whether locally or of rank and worth, μετὰ κτίλον ἕσπετο μῆλα,; κάλλιστος ἀνὴρ μετὰ *πηλείωνα, ; then of time, purpose, conformity, or adaptation, μετὰ *πάτροκλόν γε θανόντα, ‘after the death of P.’; πλεῖν μετὰ χαλκόν, ‘after,’ i. e. to get bronze; μετὰ σὸν κῆρ, ‘after,’ i. e. to suit thy heart, , , 52, , , = μέτεστι, .
μετα - βαίνω, aor. imp. μετάβηθι: pass over to a new subject, †.
μετα - βουλεύω: only aor. μετεβούλευσαν, have changed their purpose (cf. μεταφράζομαι), †.
μετ-άγγελος: messenger between two parties (internuntius, internuntia). Also written as two words, and .
μετα-δαίνυμαι, fut. μεταδαίσεται, aor. subj. μεταδαίσομαι: feast with, have a share in the feast, ἱρῶν, .
μετα-δόρπιος (δόρπος): during supper, † (cf. 213, 218).
μετα-δρομάδην: adv., running after, †.
μετα-ΐζω: sit among, †.
μετ-αΐσσω, aor. part. μεταΐξας: dart or spring after.
μετα-κιάθω, only ipf. μετεκίαθον: go after, pursue, pass over to, traverse, .
μετα - κλαίω, fut. inf. μετακλαύσεσθαι: weep afterward, lament hereafter, †.
μετα - κλίνω: only pass. aor. part. πολέμοιο μετακλινθέντος, should the tide of battle turn the other way, †.
μετα - λήγω, aor. opt. μεταλλήξειε, part. -λλήξαντι: cease from. (Il.)
μεταλλήγω: see μεταλήγω.
μετάλμενος: see μεθάλλομαι.
μετα-μάζιος: between the paps, μαζοί, †.
μετα-μίγνυμι and μετα-μίσγω, fut. μεταμίξομεν: mix among, intersperse, place in the midst, ; ‘we will merge thy possessions with those of Odysseus’ (for subsequent division among us), .
μεταμώνιος: vain, fruitless, only neut. pl. (v. l. μεταμώλια).
μετα-νάστης (ναίω): new-comer, interloper, immigrant. (Il.)
μετα-νίσσομαι: pass over (the meridian), of the sun, only w. βουλυτόνδε.
μεταξύ: between, †.
μετα-παύομαι: cease or rest between whiles, .
μετα-παυσωλή: pause between, rest, respite, †.
μετα-πρεπής, ές (πρέπω): conspicuous among, τισίν, †.
μετα-πρέπω: be conspicuous or prominent among, τισίν.
μετα-σεύομαι, ipf. μετεσσεύοντο, aor. μετέσσυτο: rush or hurry after, τινά, .
μετασπόμενος, μετασπών: see μεθέπω.
μέτασσαι (μετά): of lambs, ‘middlings,’ i. e. yearlings, summer - lambs, those born in the second of the three bearings of the year, , see .
μετασσεύομαι: see μετασεύομαι.
μετα-στένω: lament afterwards, rue, †.
μετα-στοιχί (στοῖχος): in a line, in a row, side by side, and 757.

μετα-στρέφω, fut. μεταστρέψεις, aor. subj. -ψῃ, opt. -ψειε, pass. aor. part. μεταστρεφθείς: turn about or away, change, fig., ἦτορ ἐκ χόλου, νόον, *κ 107, ; ‘cause a reverse of fortune,’ ; intr., ; so the aor. pass., , 595.
μετα-τίθημι, aor. μετέθηκεν: cause among, †.
μετα - τρέπομαι: turn oneself towards, met., regard, consider, τινός, always w. neg.
μετα - τροπαλίζομαι (τρέπω): turn about to look behind (in flight), †.
μετ-αυδάω, ipf. μετηύδων, μετηύδα: speak among, ἔπεα τισί. See αὐδάω.
μετά-φημι, ipf. μετέφη: speak among or to, τισί, also w. acc., . See φημί.
μετα - φράζομαι, fut. μεταφρασόμεσθα: consider afterward or by and by, †.
μετά-φρενον (φρένες): the part behind the diaphragm, upper part of the back; also pl., .
μετα-φωνέω (φωνή): speak among, make one's voice heard among, (sc. τοῖσι).
μετέασι: see μέτειμι 1.
μέτ-ειμι (1) (εἰμί), subj. μετείω, μετέω, inf. μετεῖναι, μετέμμεναι, fut. μετέσσομαι: be among (τισίν), intervene, .
μέτ-ειμι (2) (εἶμι), μέτεισιν, mid. aor. part. μετεισάμενος: go among, go after, go or march forth; πόλεμόνδε, .
μετ-εῖπον, μετέειπον: spoke among or to, τισί. See εἶπον.
μετεισάμενος: see μέτειμ.
μετείω, μετέμμεναι: see μέτειμ.
μετ-έπειτα: afterward.

μετ-έρχομαι, part. μετερχόμενος, fut. μετελεύσομαι, aor. 2 opt. μετέλθοι, imp. μέτελθε, part. μετελθών: come or go among (τισί), to, or after (τινά or τὶ); of seeking or pursuing, , ; πατρὸς κλέος, ; of ‘attending to’ or ‘caring for’ something, ἔργα, ἔργα γάμοιο, π 314, .
μετέσσυτο: see μετασεύομαι.
μετέω: see μέτειμι 1.
μετ - ήορος (ἀείρω, the later μετέωρος): raised aloft, into the air, , .
μετ-οίχομαι, imp. μετοίχεο, part. μετοιχόμενος, ipf. μετῴχετο: go away with or after, in friendly or hostile sense, , , .
μετ-οκλάζω: keep changing the position (from one knee to the other), †.
μετ - όπισθε: behind, in the rear, toward the west, ; afterwards, ; w. gen., .
μετ - οχλίζω, aor. opt. μετοχλίσσειε: pry or push back or away.
μετρέω, aor. part. μετρήσαντες: measure, fig. πέλαγος, of traversing its extent, †.

μέτρον: measure, measuring-rod, ; then of any vessel and its contents, ; ὅρμου μέτρον, of the proper point for mooring, ; μέτρα κελεύθου, periphrasis for κέλευθος, κέλευθα; fig., ἥβης, ‘full measure,’ ‘prime.’
μετ - ώπιον: on the forehead, and .
μέτ-ωπον (ὤψ): forehead, also front of a helmet, .
μεῦ: see ἐγώ.
μέχρι: as far as, τινός. τέο μέχρις; how long?.

μή: not, lest.—(1) adv., not, differing from οὐκ in expressing a negation subjectively. μή is the regular neg. particle with the inf., in conditions and cond. rel. clauses, in prohibitions and exhortations, in wishes, and in final clauses introduced by ἵνα, ὡς, etc. μή σε παρὰ νηυσί κιχείω, ‘let me not catch thee near the ships!’ ; ἴστω νῦν *ζεὺς.. μὴ μὲν τοῖς ἵπποισιν ἀνὴρ ἐποχήσεται ἄλλος (μή, and not οὐ, because the statement is in sense dependent on ἴστω, though grammatically the ind. is allowed to stand instead of being changed to the inf.), , cf. .—(2) conj., that not, lest (n e), introducing final clauses and object clauses after verbs of fearing, ἀπόστιχε, μή τι νοήσῃ | , ‘in order that Hera may not take note of anything,’ ; δείδω μὴ δὴ πάντα θεὰ νημερτέα ϝεῖπεν, ‘lest all the goddess said was true,’ is combined variously with other particles, μὴ δή, μὴ μάν, μή που, μή ποτε, μή πως, etc. It is joined to interrogative words only when the question expects a negative answer, ἦ μή (num), , 406, .

μηδέ: but not. and not, nor, not even, not at all; μηδέ always introduces an additional negation, after some negative idea has already been expressed or implied. It is never a correlative word; if more than one μηδέ occurs at the beginning of successive clauses, the first μηδέ refers to some previous negative idea just as much as the second one or the third one does; μηδέ τις.. οἶος μεμάτω μάχεσθαι, μηδ' ἀναχωρείτω, ; here the first μηδέ means and not, nor, the direct quotation being regarded as a continuation of what precedes in the indirect form. Usually μηδέ at the beginning of a sentence means not even or not at all. For the difference between μηδέ and οὐδέ, see μή. See also οὐδέ, fin.
μηδέν: nothing, †.
: a natural daughter of Priam, wife of Imbrius, †.
μήδομαι, fut. μήσεαι, aor. μήσαο, (ἐ）μήσατο: take counsel for oneself, ; devise (τινί τι), esp. in bad sense; decide upon (τὶ), .
μῆδος (1), εος: only pl., μήδεα, plans, counsels.
μῆδος (2), εος: pl., privy parts. (Od.)
: a city in Magnesia, the home of Philoctētes, .

μηκάομαι, aor. part. μακών, perf., w. pres. signif., μεμηκώς, μεμακυῖαι, ipf., formed on perf. stem., (ἐ）μέμηκον: of sheep, bleat; of wounded animals, or game hard-pressed, cry, shriek, ; once of a man, .
μηκάς, άδος (μηκάομαι): bleating (of goats).
μηκ-έτι: no longer, no more.
: (1) son of Talaus, brother of Adrastus, and father of Euryalus, , .—(2) son of Echius, companion of Antilochus, slain by Polydamas, , , .
: son of Mecisteus, Euryalus, .
μήκιστος: tallest; as adv., μήκιστα, finally, .
μῆκος: length, lofty stature, .
μήκων, ωνος: poppy, †.
μηλέη (μῆλον): apple-tree. (Od.)
μηλο-βοτήρ, ῆρος: shepherd, pl., †.
μῆλον (1): apple (mālum).
μῆλον (2): sheep or goat, , ; mostly pl., μῆλα, small cattle, flocks.
μῆλοψ, οπος: probably shining, †.
μήν: asseverative particle, indeed, in truth, verily, cf. μάν and μέν (2). μήν regularly stands in combination with another particle (καὶ μήν, ἦ μήν, οὐ μήν), or with an imperative like ἄγε, .
μήν, μηνός: see μείς.
μήνη: moon, and .
μηνιθμός (μηνίω): wrath. (）
μήνιμα, ατος: cause of wrath.
μῆνις, ιος: wrath, i. e. enduring anger, usually of gods, , ; but also of the wrath of Achilles.
μηνίω, aor. part. μηνίσας: be wroth, abs., and w. dat. of pers., also causal gen. of thing. μήνιεν, .
: the Maeonians, i. e. the Lydians, , .
: Maeonia, ancient name of Lydia, .
, ίδος: Maeonian woman, .
μήποτε, μήπου, μήπω, μήπως: see μή and ποτέ, πού, πώ, πώς.
μῆρα: see μηρίον.
μήρινθος (μηρύω): cord. (）
μηρίον: only pl., μηρία and μῆρα, pieces of meat from the thighs (μηροί) of victims, thigh - pieces, which were burned upon the altar, wrapped in a double layer of fat, , .
: Meriones or Merion, the son of Molus, a Cretan, charioteer of Idomeneus, , 249, 528, 566, 650,, , , , 603.

μηρός: ham, upper part of the thigh; μηρὼ πλήσσεσθαι, to ‘smite the thighs,’ a gesture indicative of surprise or other excitement, , ; of victims, μηροὺς ἐξέταμον, i. e. cut out the μηρία from the μηροί, *α 460, .
μηρύομαι, aor. μηρύσαντο: draw up, furl by brailing up; ἱστία, †. (See cut No. 5, an Egyptian representation of a Phoenician ship.)

μήστωρ, ωρος (μήδομαι): counsellor, deviser; ὕπατος μήστωρ, Zeus, ; θεόφιν μ. ἀτάλαντος, of heroes with reference to their wisdom, , 409; w. ref. to prowess, ἀυτῆς, φόβοιο, ‘raiser’ of the battle-cry, ‘author’ of flight, , .
: a son of Priam, †.
μήτε (μή τε): regularly correlative, μήτε.. μήτε, neither.. nor, (not） either.. or, dividing a single neg. statement. μήτε.. τε, . For the difference between μήτε and οὔτε, see μή.
μήτηρ, μητέρος and μητρός: mother; epithets, πότνια, αἰδοίη, κεδνή; fig., μήτηρ μήλων, θηρῶν, of regions abounding in sheep, game, etc., , .
μήτι: see μήτις.
μήτι: see μῆτις.

μητιάω (μῆτις), 3 pl. μητιόωσι, part. μητιόωσα, μητιόωντες, mid. pres. μητιάασθε, ipf. μητιόωντο: deliberate, conclude, devise, abs., and w. acc., βουλάς, νόστον, κακά τινι, *υ 153, ; mid., debate with oneself, consider, , .
μητίετα (μητίομαι), nom., for -της: counselling, ‘all-wise,’ epith. of Zeus.
μητιόεις, pl. -εντα (μῆτις): full of device, helpful, φάρμακα, †.
μητίομαι (μῆτις), fut. μητίσομαι, aor. subj. μητίσομαι, opt. μητισαίμην, inf. μητίσασθαι: devise, perpetrate upon, τινί τι, and τινά τι, .
μητιόωσα, μητιόωσι: see μητιάω.
μῆτις, ιος, dat. μήτι: counsel, wis- dom, , ; concretely, plan, device, μῆτιν ὑφαίνειν, τεκταίνεσθαι, *η 324, .

μήτις, μήτι (μή τις, μή τι): no one, not anything, adv., μήτι, not at all, by no means; for the difference between μήτις and οὔτις, see μή. In , εἰ μὲν δὴ μήτις σε βιάζεται, μήτις shows that the other Cyclōpes understood Polyphēmus to say οὔτις in v. 408 instead of (he said ‘Noman,’ but they thought he said no man).
μητρο-πάτωρ: mother's father, maternal grandfather, †.
μητρυιή: step-mother. (Il.)
μητρώιος: of a mother, maternal, δῶμα, †.
μήτρως, ωος: maternal uncle. (Il.)
μηχανάω, μηχανάομαι (μηχανή), part. μηχανόωντας, ind. 3 pl. μηχανόωνται, opt. μηχανόῳτο, ipf. μηχανόωντο: contrive, set at work, perpetrate, freq. in unfavorable sense.
μῆχος, εος: help, remedy.
: see .
μία: see εἷς.
μιαίνω, aor. subj. μιήνῃ, pass. pres. inf. μιαίνεσθαι, ipf. ἐμιαίνετο, aor. 3 pl. ἐμίανθεν: dye, stain, soil. (Il.)
μιαι-φόνος: blood - stained, epith. of Ares. (Il.)
μιαρός: stained (with blood), †.
μιγάζομαι = μίγνυμαι, part., †.
μίγδα: promiscuously, together, , .
